headline: Electric 2-wheelers to see 16-18% volume growth in FY28 as rare-earth supply eases: Crisil
condensed_text:
(representative image)
The easing of rare-earth supply is expected to drive electric two-wheeler volume growth in India to 16-18 per cent next fiscal after moderating to 12-13 per cent in the ongoing fiscal due to supply chain constraints, according to Crisil Ratings. This fiscal, the electric two-wheeler (E2W) growth is expected to moderate due to temporary disruptions in the supply of rare-earth magnets and the goods and services tax (GST) rationalisation on internal combustion engine (ICE) models, Crisil Ratings said in a statement. “With supply conditions improving, reflecting a gradual resumption of inflow of magnets from China alongside initial steps by OEMs to diversify sourcing, growth is expected to re-accelerate to 16-18 per cent next fiscal, assuming stable availability of rare-earth magnets," Sethi said. “An analysis of 10 original equipment manufacturers (OEMs), comprising four legacy players with ICE and E2W portfolios and six new-age, EV-only players, indicates as much," it said, adding these OEMs account for about 85 per cent of the E2W volume. While GST rate cuts have reduced the purchase cost of ICE vehicles, running costs favour E2Ws, at about 3 paisa/km versus ₹2-2.5/km for ICE, continuing their advantage in total cost of ownership even as subsidies taper, it said.
full_content:
(representative image)
The easing of rare-earth supply is expected to drive electric two-wheeler volume growth in India to 16-18 per cent next fiscal after moderating to 12-13 per cent in the ongoing fiscal due to supply chain constraints, according to Crisil Ratings.
This fiscal, the electric two-wheeler (E2W) growth is expected to moderate due to temporary disruptions in the supply of rare-earth magnets and the goods and services tax (GST) rationalisation on internal combustion engine (ICE) models, Crisil Ratings said in a statement.
In the previous fiscal, E2W volume growth was at 22 per cent, it added.
“The supply disruption caused by the shortage of rare-earth magnets had weighed on E2W volumes around mid-year. As availability began to ease, coinciding with the GST-led price revision in ICE models, OEMs relied on discounting and introduced lower-priced electric models to narrow the ICE-EV price gap,” Crisil Ratings Senior Director Anuj Sethi said.
While this has supported a recovery in volumes in recent months, the impact of the earlier supply disruption is expected to limit full-year growth to 12-13 per cent, he added.
“With supply conditions improving, reflecting a gradual resumption of inflow of magnets from China alongside initial steps by OEMs to diversify sourcing, growth is expected to re-accelerate to 16-18 per cent next fiscal, assuming stable availability of rare-earth magnets," Sethi said.
Crisil Ratings said the expected growth of 16-18 per cent is supported by a structural ownership-cost advantage. However, competitive pressure is creating divergent risk profiles, with legacy players better insulated, while new-age players continue to face weak unit-vehicle economics.
“An analysis of 10 original equipment manufacturers (OEMs), comprising four legacy players with ICE and E2W portfolios and six new-age, EV-only players, indicates as much," it said, adding these OEMs account for about 85 per cent of the E2W volume.
E2W adoption continues to be supported by strong vehicle economics. While GST rate cuts have reduced the purchase cost of ICE vehicles, running costs favour E2Ws, at about 3 paisa/km versus ₹2-2.5/km for ICE, continuing their advantage in total cost of ownership even as subsidies taper, it said.
With incentives being phased out and the pace of decline in battery cost (which accounts for 35-40 per cent of total costs) slowing after a sharp correction over the past two fiscals, Crisil Ratings said price-led competition has narrowed.
Increasingly, reliability and service are becoming more important differentiators, and this is where legacy OEMs are scoring high at present, it added.
“The market share of legacy players has increased to 62 per cent by January 2026 from 47 per cent a year earlier, clearly outperforming new-age players," Crisil Ratings Director, Poonam Upadhyay, said.
The share gain reflects their stronger dealer reach and supplier ecosystems, alongside an expanded range of entry-level and mid-priced electric models that enable faster rollout, wider availability, and more consistent execution, Upadhyay noted.
Published on  February 4, 2026
BACK TO TOP

headline: Hyundai Motor India plans to lift exports share to 30% of production by FY30
condensed_text: What's your own estimate for FY27?A: In fact, now we are already at the end of FY26, and it's better to talk about even FY27, and we had a Society of Indian Automobile Manufacturers  conclave where all the auto original equipment manufacturers  were present, and the consensus was about 5 to 6% growth for the industry. Will it stay around this 11.2–11.3% sort of band despite commodity inflation?A: During our Investor Day, we have already given guidance that our EBITDA margins will stay between 11% and 14%, and we are fairly confident of meeting those expectations going forward as well.Q: Is there another price hike on the anvil?A: Ideally, we don't want to do price hikes, and we always try to do cost optimisation. The demographics of India, a very strong plant structure, and a very high level of quality put us in a very good position to continuously look for opportunities for increasing exports.Also Read | PG Electroplast holds FY26 target, waits for channel inventory to clear, summer salesHyundai has been very strong in India in terms of exporting since the time we set foot in India. So, the plans are very much intact, and we are fairly confident that exports will only go up from here.Q: Since you spoke about increased capacity helping your exports, could you tell us what your current capacity utilisation is, and when do you get to this 30% contribution coming in from exports?A: The current capacity is now almost 824,000 in Chennai and 170,000 in Pune. The current level is about 23 to 24%.Q: Lastly, could you talk to us about the strategy behind the foray into the commercial mobility segment?A: I think this is a very interesting segment, and we have seen the segment really grow, especially post COVID, in the last three to four years, when people are looking for shared mobility.
full_content: Hyundai Motor India plans to increase exports as part of its long-term production strategy, according to Managing Director and CEO Tarun Garg. The company is focusing on using its existing manufacturing capacity to support both domestic and export demand.Hyundai plans to increase the share of exports in total production over the next few years. Garg said exports currently contribute about 23–24% of total production. He said, “we intend to go to 30%.” The company has set this as a long-term target for the fiscal year 2029-30 .The company currently has total production capacity of about 994,000 units across its plants. He said the company has about 824,000 units of capacity in Chennai and about 170,000 units in Pune.He said exports have remained a key part of Hyundai’s India operations since it entered the country. He said the company continues to be the largest exporter among auto manufacturers in India on a cumulative basis. He said, “exports have been a great driver.”Hyundai Motor India reported single-digit growth in revenue and operating profit on a year-on-year basis for the October–December 2025 quarter. The company continues to focus on balancing domestic sales and exports to support growth.The company currently has a market capitalisation of ₹1,78,954.05 crore. Its shares have gained more than 18% over the last year.These are the edited excerpts of the interview.Q: In January, the volumes rose to close to 12%, with the highest ever monthly sales. Could you tell us how quarter four is shaping up so far?A: I think it's a very positive sign. And we can see positive momentum everywhere. Thanks to goods and services tax  2.0, we saw in the October to December quarter also a lot of retail momentum. And what happened was because we were able to make space in the network inventory, January also started on a very positive note, and we are seeing growth across segments.For example, Aura clocked the highest ever sales. The new Venue has received a great response, almost 80,000 bookings and highest ever sales again, Creta continues to be very strong, so I think we can be much more positive about quarter four. I don't like to put a number to it, but as things stand now, the momentum seems to be very strong.Q: Most brokerages have raised their passenger vehicle  industry outlook, especially post the recent volume upmove that has happened. What's your own estimate for the industry? Not particularly for you. What's your own estimate for FY27?A: In fact, now we are already at the end of FY26, and it's better to talk about even FY27, and we had a Society of Indian Automobile Manufacturers  conclave where all the auto original equipment manufacturers  were present, and the consensus was about 5 to 6% growth for the industry. I'm sure Hyundai would like to beat that.Also Read | Bajaj Auto sees export run-rate holding above 2 lakh units a monthAnd like I said, the calendar year has started on a very positive note. And we believe that, because the growth is everywhere, and the maximum growth is coming in the compact SUV segment, where the new Venue has received a great response, and we are looking at avenues to increase the production further, because we have a great backlog of orders. So, we can sustain this kind of momentum going forward in FY26–27 also. And as we already announced in the investor day, our new model has already kicked in with the Venue, and more models will come in. I think all that should help us to carry this momentum to the next fiscal.Q: You reported an increase in realisation of around 3%. I assume you've taken a price hike. If you could give us some clarity on that particular aspect.A: If you see the last quarter, in January 2025 we had a price increase of about 0.7%, and obviously that effect has helped until December - October to December quarter. And obviously we had some very strong cost optimisation measures. We have a very strong quality of growth strategy. Even post GST, we were very disciplined in our discount levels, which remained less than 3%.So, all in all, all these factors have helped us to have growth in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation  margins and growth in topline as well as in bottom line. Exports also helped. We had a 21% growth in exports last quarter on a year-on-year  basis. And I think exports continue to be a very strong pillar in HMI’s quest for volume and profitability.Q: Since you spoke about profitability, let's talk about the margins. Will it stay around this 11.2–11.3% sort of band despite commodity inflation?A: During our Investor Day, we have already given guidance that our EBITDA margins will stay between 11% and 14%, and we are fairly confident of meeting those expectations going forward as well.Q: Is there another price hike on the anvil?A: Ideally, we don't want to do price hikes, and we always try to do cost optimisation. So, we'll watch the commodity prices, we'll see what the pressures are, and we'll take a decision as and when required. But obviously, the endeavour is always to avoid price hikes as much as possible, to do cost optimisation and other measures in terms of saving cost or localisation or the trim strategy, the quality of sales strategy. So, I think that will continue to be our endeavour going forward as well, unless it becomes imperative to pass on some of the cost to the customers. But let's see.We will watch the commodity prices. The volatility is so high. You have seen how things are moving, especially precious metals. So, I think we need to have a close watch on that.Q: Exports have been a growth driver, and you briefly mentioned them in the past. Could you tell us what's the strategy with regard to exports from here on?A: We have headroom because of the additional capacity in the Pune plant. So, we have accelerated on the exports. We are Hyundai Motor Company’s  hub outside of Korea for the emerging markets. The new Venue is produced exclusively in India. This will present some new opportunities for us. The Middle East is doing very well in exports, Latin America as well. The new model cycle is kicking in. So we look at those models also helping us in exports.In the mid-term, all these FTAs are also very exciting, and we still need to go through the details — India-EU, whether there is any opportunity there. So, we'll be very open and positive. The demographics of India, a very strong plant structure, and a very high level of quality put us in a very good position to continuously look for opportunities for increasing exports.Also Read | PG Electroplast holds FY26 target, waits for channel inventory to clear, summer salesHyundai has been very strong in India in terms of exporting since the time we set foot in India. On a cumulative basis, we still hold the position of being the number one exporter. And in the last 12 to 15 months, exports have been a great driver. Already, we have announced that from the current level of 23 to 24% contribution of exports to overall production, we intend to go to 30%. So, the plans are very much intact, and we are fairly confident that exports will only go up from here.Q: Since you spoke about increased capacity helping your exports, could you tell us what your current capacity utilisation is, and when do you get to this 30% contribution coming in from exports?A: The current capacity is now almost 824,000 in Chennai and 170,000 in Pune. So, 994,000 is our capacity. So, we have enough capacity now. And that 30% is, of course, for FY30. So that is a long-term plan. The current level is about 23 to 24%.Q: Lastly, could you talk to us about the strategy behind the foray into the commercial mobility segment?A: I think this is a very interesting segment, and we have seen the segment really grow, especially post COVID, in the last three to four years, when people are looking for shared mobility. So, I think Hyundai is a strong brand and has very strong products, along with the factory-fitted CNG option, both in the hatchback as well as in the sedan segment. So, we've introduced it in January. The initial response is very encouraging, especially in the sedan segment. That has helped us clock the highest ever Aura sales.And overall, the products are very reliable. We have a very comprehensive strategy. It's not only about the product. Our dealers are ready. We are tying up with financiers. The service packages are there to give comfort to the operators. So, we are fairly confident that we will be able to make a strong mark in this segment, where the competition is not very strong and very few players have the right product to tap this taxi segment.For the full interview, watch the accompanying videoCatch all the latest updates from the stock market here

headline: IndusInd Bank sees no loan stress in gems and jewellery portfolio despite sector slowdown
condensed_text: Despite the gems and jewellery sector facing sustained pressure for more than a year, Rajiv Anand, Managing Director and Chief Executive Officer of IndusInd Bank, said the bank’s exposure to the segment continues to remain asset-quality stable, with no accounts slipping into stress categories.The gems and jewellery portfolio accounts for around 3% of the bank’s total loan book, or roughly ₹9,500 crore. The sector, he said, has gone through a difficult phase over the past 12 to 18 months, mainly due to tariff-related issues and a sharp drop in demand from China after the pandemic.However, Anand underlined that the bank has not seen any slippages in this portfolio. Reflecting the muted operating environment, he said the bank’s loan book to the gems and jewellery sector has not grown over the past year.Anand said the recently concluded US–India trade deal, which fixes a flat tariff of 18%, is a clear positive for the industry and should support exports going ahead. Even so, he cautioned that it is still too early to estimate how much incremental lending could emerge from this improvement, and the bank will first engage with its existing clients before firming up growth plans.On the bank’s broader micro, small, and medium enterprises  portfolio with exposure to US exports, Anand said the impact of tariffs has been relatively muted, as many borrowers had already diversified their buyer base.Also Read: Budget borrowing surprise may nudge yields up, RBI support expected: IndusInd Bank CEOResponding to questions around recent senior management appointments and organisational changes, Anand said the bank continues to follow all regulatory and disclosure requirements and will keep informing stock exchanges whenever senior personnel join.On capital, Anand said the bank remains comfortably placed, with a capital adequacy ratio of 17% and a Common Equity Tier-1 ratio of 15.8%. So therefore, to that extent, we don't envisage a capital raise in the near to medium term,” he said, ruling out any immediate plans to raise capital.For the entire interview, watch the accompanying videoCatch all the latest updates from the stock market here
full_content: Despite the gems and jewellery sector facing sustained pressure for more than a year, Rajiv Anand, Managing Director and Chief Executive Officer of IndusInd Bank, said the bank’s exposure to the segment continues to remain asset-quality stable, with no accounts slipping into stress categories.The gems and jewellery portfolio accounts for around 3% of the bank’s total loan book, or roughly ₹9,500 crore. The sector, he said, has gone through a difficult phase over the past 12 to 18 months, mainly due to tariff-related issues and a sharp drop in demand from China after the pandemic.However, Anand underlined that the bank has not seen any slippages in this portfolio. “We deal pretty much with the largest players in this space,” he said, adding that since there were no special mention accounts, SMA-1 or SMA-2, there was no need to raise provisions. Reflecting the muted operating environment, he said the bank’s loan book to the gems and jewellery sector has not grown over the past year.Anand said the recently concluded US–India trade deal, which fixes a flat tariff of 18%, is a clear positive for the industry and should support exports going ahead. “This is not just positive for gems but for diamonds as well because lab-grown diamond is a big market in the US, and that should have a positive impact for some of our customers as well,” he said. Even so, he cautioned that it is still too early to estimate how much incremental lending could emerge from this improvement, and the bank will first engage with its existing clients before firming up growth plans.On the bank’s broader micro, small, and medium enterprises  portfolio with exposure to US exports, Anand said the impact of tariffs has been relatively muted, as many borrowers had already diversified their buyer base.Also Read: Budget borrowing surprise may nudge yields up, RBI support expected: IndusInd Bank CEOResponding to questions around recent senior management appointments and organisational changes, Anand said the bank continues to follow all regulatory and disclosure requirements and will keep informing stock exchanges whenever senior personnel join.On capital, Anand said the bank remains comfortably placed, with a capital adequacy ratio of 17% and a Common Equity Tier-1 ratio of 15.8%. “Currently, we are very comfortable as far as capital is concerned. So therefore, to that extent, we don't envisage a capital raise in the near to medium term,” he said, ruling out any immediate plans to raise capital.For the entire interview, watch the accompanying videoCatch all the latest updates from the stock market here

headline: Emcure Pharma Q3 Results: Strong operating performance but stock gives up gains
condensed_text: Emcure Pharmaceuticals reported a strong set of December-quarter earnings, with consolidated net profit jumping 50% year-on-year to ₹230.5 crore, aided by robust revenue growth across domestic and international markets and margin expansion, despite a one-time hit from labour code-related costs.The company, in an exchange filing on Wednesday, February 4, said that its revenue from operations rose 20.4% from last year to ₹2,363 crore in the December quarter, compared with ₹1,962 crore a year earlier.Earnings Before Interest Tax Depreciation and Amortisation  climbed 39% from the year-ago period to ₹493 crore, while operating margin expanded to 20.8% from 18% in the same period last year.According to Emcure Pharma, profit growth was driven by strong traction across key therapies in India and sustained momentum in overseas markets. Domestic formulations revenue increased 15.4% from last year to ₹1,025 crore, led by chronic segments such as cardio and diabetes, while international business grew 24.5% to ₹1,338 crore, with broad-based growth across regions.Emcure’s Rest of the World business rose 30.7%, while Europe and Canada posted growth of 29.6% and 12.8%, respectively. During the quarter, the company also launched Poviztra, a biological injectable semaglutide, in partnership with Novo Nordisk, strengthening its presence in the fast-growing weight management segment.Read more: Five stocks, including Tata Motors CV could enter the Nifty Next 50 in March; Check potential inflowsProfitability, however, was partly impacted by an exceptional expense of about ₹38 crore, largely on account of a one-time charge related to the implementation of India’s new labour codes.Commenting on the performance, Managing Director and CEO Satish Mehta said, "Q3 delivered a strong performance, with all our businesses outpacing industry growth." Emcure continues to focus on profitability alongside investing in products, people and processes, he added.For the nine months ended December 2025, Emcure reported consolidated net profit of ₹1,116 crore, compared with ₹1,149 crore a year ago, reflecting the impact of exceptional costs during the period. Revenue for the nine months stood at ₹6,734 crore, up from ₹5,780 crore last year.The board also approved the appointment of Amruta Jana Yangalwar as Company Secretary and Compliance Officer and cleared the reappointment of three independent directors, subject to shareholder approval.Shares of Emcure Pharma are off the highs of the day after the results announcement to trade at ₹1,521.9.

During the quarter, the company also launched Poviztra, a biological injectable semaglutide, in partnership with Novo Nordisk, strengthening its presence in the fast-growing weight management segment.Read more: Five stocks, including Tata Motors CV could enter the Nifty Next 50 in March; Check potential inflowsProfitability, however, was partly impacted by an exceptional expense of about ₹38 crore, largely on account of a one-time charge related to the implementation of India’s new labour codes.Commenting on the performance, Managing Director and CEO Satish Mehta said, "Q3 delivered a strong performance, with all our businesses outpacing industry growth." Emcure continues to focus on profitability alongside investing in products, people and processes, he added.For the nine months ended December 2025, Emcure reported consolidated net profit of ₹1,116 crore, compared with ₹1,149 crore a year ago, reflecting the impact of exceptional costs during the period. Revenue for the nine months stood at ₹6,734 crore, up from ₹5,780 crore last year.The board also approved the appointment of Amruta Jana Yangalwar as Company Secretary and Compliance Officer and cleared the reappointment of three independent directors, subject to shareholder approval.Shares of Emcure Pharma are off the highs of the day after the results announcement to trade at ₹1,521.9. The stock is up 8% in the last six months.

headline: Welspun Corp expects to beat this year's profit target, sees Sintex turnaround in FY27
condensed_text: Despite a challenging operating environment in parts of its portfolio, Vipul Mathur, Managing Director and Chief Executive Officer of Welspun Corp, said the company is on course to surpass its full-year earnings guidance, backed by strong execution and a robust order pipeline.After reporting nearly ₹1,800 crore of earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation  in the first nine months of 2025-26 , Mathur said the company is now well placed to exceed its earlier full-year guidance of ₹2,200 crore, with around ₹2,500 crore increasingly looking achievable.Welspun Corp, based in Mumbai, has a market capitalisation of about ₹21,578.07 crore, and its shares have gained close to 14% over the past year.Mathur refrained from committing to a specific number for 2026-27 , but reiterated the company’s internal target of delivering 15% year-on-year EBITDA growth, supported by a “very, very strong order book in America, a very strong order book in India, and a very strong business visibility”.On the government’s Jal Jeevan Mission , Mathur said spending had remained muted last year due to procedural issues, even though allocations were in place. He added that the fresh budget allocation is a positive development and that payment-related bottlenecks, which had forced engineering, procurement and construction  companies to slow execution, are now easing. “Now that the payments have started coming in, I’m sure that we will see a lot of traction,” he said.Also Read: Data centre expansion fuels new growth avenue for Welspun Corp, says Vipul MathurWelspun Corp’s direct exposure to JJM, he added, is relatively small at under ₹100 crore and is largely with government entities, making it a secure exposure. He said a revenue milestone of ₹1,000 crore in the next financial year is “definitely possible”, a level at which the company has earlier indicated it could explore options to unlock value.Also Read: Davos 2026: Welspun group is expanding in energy sector with $500 million investment, says BK GoenkaMathur also highlighted the sharp improvement at Welspun Specialty Solutions, calling it a “classic textbook turnaround story”. While detailed guidance will be provided after the January-March quarter of 2026  results, he indicated that revenue of about ₹1,100 crore with high single-digit margins in the next year is a realistic possibility, and confirmed that the company will continue to operate as a separate listed entity.For the entire interview, watch the accompanying videoCatch all the latest updates from the stock market here
full_content: Despite a challenging operating environment in parts of its portfolio, Vipul Mathur, Managing Director and Chief Executive Officer of Welspun Corp, said the company is on course to surpass its full-year earnings guidance, backed by strong execution and a robust order pipeline.After reporting nearly ₹1,800 crore of earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation  in the first nine months of 2025-26 , Mathur said the company is now well placed to exceed its earlier full-year guidance of ₹2,200 crore, with around ₹2,500 crore increasingly looking achievable.Welspun Corp, based in Mumbai, has a market capitalisation of about ₹21,578.07 crore, and its shares have gained close to 14% over the past year.Mathur refrained from committing to a specific number for 2026-27 , but reiterated the company’s internal target of delivering 15% year-on-year EBITDA growth, supported by a “very, very strong order book in America, a very strong order book in India, and a very strong business visibility”.On the government’s Jal Jeevan Mission , Mathur said spending had remained muted last year due to procedural issues, even though allocations were in place. He added that the fresh budget allocation is a positive development and that payment-related bottlenecks, which had forced engineering, procurement and construction  companies to slow execution, are now easing. “Now that the payments have started coming in, I’m sure that we will see a lot of traction,” he said.Also Read: Data centre expansion fuels new growth avenue for Welspun Corp, says Vipul MathurWelspun Corp’s direct exposure to JJM, he added, is relatively small at under ₹100 crore and is largely with government entities, making it a secure exposure. He expects outstanding dues linked to the scheme to be largely settled by the first quarter of the next financial year.A key focus area for the company is the revival of its Sintex business. Mathur said the slower-than-expected ramp-up was mainly due to stress in the water and building construction segments. With both sectors now showing signs of recovery, he expects a meaningful performance improvement and described the next year as a potential turnaround phase for the business. He said a revenue milestone of ₹1,000 crore in the next financial year is “definitely possible”, a level at which the company has earlier indicated it could explore options to unlock value.Also Read: Davos 2026: Welspun group is expanding in energy sector with $500 million investment, says BK GoenkaMathur also highlighted the sharp improvement at Welspun Specialty Solutions, calling it a “classic textbook turnaround story”. He pointed to strong demand visibility driven by higher government spending in defence, nuclear and power sectors, as well as the broader Atmanirbhar Bharat push. While detailed guidance will be provided after the January-March quarter of 2026  results, he indicated that revenue of about ₹1,100 crore with high single-digit margins in the next year is a realistic possibility, and confirmed that the company will continue to operate as a separate listed entity.For the entire interview, watch the accompanying videoCatch all the latest updates from the stock market here

headline: Nazara Technologies says core business improving, more acquisitions on radar
condensed_text: Nazara Technologies is focusing on expanding its core gaming business and pursuing acquisitions as part of its growth strategy, even as headline revenue and profit remained under pressure in the October–December 2025 quarter.Joint MD and CEO of the company, Nitish Mittersain, said operating performance improved during the period.Nazara, which currently has a market capitalisation of ₹10,335.97 crore, has seen its shares rise more than 15% over the past year.These are edited excerpts of the interview.Q: If I look at the reported numbers, the overall reported revenue is down 24%, and the net profit is down 64%. Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation  is fairly strong, but a large part of that has to do with the deconsolidation of the sports business and some of the acquisitions that you've made over the course of the last year as well. And the best part is that our cost per acquisition has come down from $37 to $35.4, so we've been able to spend more but at lower costs, which makes us feel that we can get growth going strongly in the coming quarters.Also Read | A made-in-India global gaming powerhouse: CEO Nitish Mittersain's ambition for NazaraQ: In terms of the investments that you're making in the business so far, what has been the total dollar value of investments that you've made in the company so far, and will you be making more? A good part of that is that they will support all these studios that we acquire and add a lot of synergy and value to them.Q: The dollar value of total investments that you've made in the company so far — because organic growth is at around 10% — one sense is that you'll be raising funds for funding growth going forward. And if we require additional capital, we will raise capital.What we are very focused on is to ensure that if there is any capital raise and there is dilution to the shareholders, the accretion in terms of cash flows from the businesses that we acquire is far more rewarding than the dilution.
full_content: Nazara Technologies is focusing on expanding its core gaming business and pursuing acquisitions as part of its growth strategy, even as headline revenue and profit remained under pressure in the October–December 2025 quarter.Joint MD and CEO of the company, Nitish Mittersain, said operating performance improved during the period.Nazara, which currently has a market capitalisation of ₹10,335.97 crore, has seen its shares rise more than 15% over the past year.These are edited excerpts of the interview.Q: If I look at the reported numbers, the overall reported revenue is down 24%, and the net profit is down 64%. Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation  is fairly strong, but a large part of that has to do with the deconsolidation of the sports business and some of the acquisitions that you've made over the course of the last year as well. So organically, excluding all the acquisitions and deconsolidation, on a like-to-like basis, what has been the revenue and profitability growth for you?A: So, revenue growth is 10%. Profitability growth would be upwards of 25%. But just to take a step back, the revenue decline at the headline number is typically because of the deconsolidation. Our focus on core gaming continues to progress very well. And our EBITDA margins in this quarter have increased significantly to 16.8%. So, we're very much on the right track. We are executing what we said we would execute, and the numbers are tracking what we expect.Q: One of the positives was with regard to Kiddopia and the resumption of subscriptions and subscribers. There were many quarters where we saw a decline, and now that's picked up. What's the outlook from here on? Does this addition continue? And would you say the worst is behind for the Kiddopia business?A: Fundamentally, since last year, we have created these centres of excellence in user acquisition, in data analytics, in artificial intelligence  and product. What the centres of excellence are doing is supporting each of our games and our studios to enhance the way they are operating. And the first positive impact, and tangible impact, you can see is in Kiddopia.We were struggling to add to the subscriber base for quite some time, and this quarter we've been able to show a net positive impact. And the best part is that our cost per acquisition has come down from $37 to $35.4, so we've been able to spend more but at lower costs, which makes us feel that we can get growth going strongly in the coming quarters.Also Read | A made-in-India global gaming powerhouse: CEO Nitish Mittersain's ambition for NazaraQ: In terms of the investments that you're making in the business so far, what has been the total dollar value of investments that you've made in the company so far, and will you be making more? Are you looking at some sort of shareholder fundraising?A: We are continuing to invest, one, organically in our existing businesses. That is very important. If you see any of our games, like Animal Jam has been launched on Roblox.We've signed new licences for TV shows globally. We recently launched a Big Brother game. There's a lot of investment that's going into existing business, and we are also actively pursuing new acquisitions of gaming studios, and continue to be in advanced talks with a few, so that may happen. I think we will continue with these new centres of excellence that we have created. A good part of that is that they will support all these studios that we acquire and add a lot of synergy and value to them.Q: The dollar value of total investments that you've made in the company so far — because organic growth is at around 10% — one sense is that you'll be raising funds for funding growth going forward. So, you will be using shareholders' money to buy growth. That's the point here. So, if you could give us the dollar value of the investment.A: Over many years, we would have invested a lot of capital. But in the last year, we did two key acquisitions — Fusebox Games and WildWorks. Between the two, we invested capital of about ₹500 crore or less. Currently, the company has about ₹700 crore worth of net cash on its balance sheet. And if we require additional capital, we will raise capital.What we are very focused on is to ensure that if there is any capital raise and there is dilution to the shareholders, the accretion in terms of cash flows from the businesses that we acquire is far more rewarding than the dilution. So, we are very conscious of that. The one metric we are looking at is cash flow per share. It should be significantly improved by any action that we take.Q: And if you're doing a dilution, what could it be to the tune of? Will it be ₹500 crore, ₹800 crore, or ₹1,000 crore kind of dilution?A: If we do, perhaps in that range. But there is nothing final at this point in time.For the full interview, watch the accompanying videoCatch all the latest updates from the stock market here

headline: Awfis sees 30% growth in FY26 as demand for flexible offices stays strong
condensed_text: Amit Ramani, Chairman and Managing Director of Awfis Space Solutions, remains confident about the company’s growth trajectory, reiterating its guidance of around 30% overall growth for FY26.He highlighted that the co-working and allied services segment continues to outperform, driven by strong demand momentum and increasing adoption by enterprises seeking flexible workspace solutions.Ramani attributed this momentum largely to the accelerating adoption of flexible workspaces by Global Capability Centres , especially first-time entrants into India.He explained that co-working has increasingly become the preferred first port of call for such companies, as it allows them to set up operations quickly without committing to long-term real estate investments, while also offering scalability as teams expand.In October-December quarter , Awfis Space Solutions reported revenues of ₹382 crore, profit after tax of ₹22 crore and margins at 36.5%.These are edited excerpts of the interview.Q: Can you give us a sense of what the FY26 outlook is looking like? The growth in every sector related to GCCs, as well as if you look at now, even with the Budget, with the AI and the data centre companies, and this solutioning that is going to provide tax holidays is only going to help and improve the sector.Q: You have 152,000 seats, when do we expect this number to double from here?A: So last year, we added about 40,000 seats. So, 32,000 for this year, next year, we will provide that guidance in the next quarter itself.Q: Since you said you are at the highest level of commercial rentals, even volumes and pricing are going in tandem, so I wanted to understand, what would the risk to some of the big opportunities that there are in the industry currently? So, the growth engines and the drivers for co-working, overall, for commercial real estate, are very strong.For co-working, it's a first port of call, especially for the first time GCCs, they do not have their teams in India, and as a result, co-working and flex provides a great solutioning. But I think there is a very clear approach that we are taking where we have to balance the seat addition with the growth and the profitability at the same time.If you look at our numbers, we did about ₹22 crores of PAT at this point, and for the year or nine month period, we are almost ₹50 crores of PAT.
full_content: Amit Ramani, Chairman and Managing Director of Awfis Space Solutions, remains confident about the company’s growth trajectory, reiterating its guidance of around 30% overall growth for FY26.He highlighted that the co-working and allied services segment continues to outperform, driven by strong demand momentum and increasing adoption by enterprises seeking flexible workspace solutions.Ramani attributed this momentum largely to the accelerating adoption of flexible workspaces by Global Capability Centres , especially first-time entrants into India.He explained that co-working has increasingly become the preferred first port of call for such companies, as it allows them to set up operations quickly without committing to long-term real estate investments, while also offering scalability as teams expand.In October-December quarter , Awfis Space Solutions reported revenues of ₹382 crore, profit after tax of ₹22 crore and margins at 36.5%.These are edited excerpts of the interview.Q: Can you give us a sense of what the FY26 outlook is looking like? Also, now if you have more clarity on FY27 as well, because we are almost done with FY26 what kind of seat additions, revenue growth and margin outlook are you looking at?A: The guidance for FY26 continues to remain what we had given originally about a 30% growth for the overall business. As you see in the nine month period, the co-working and allied services grew much faster, at about almost 38% and for the quarter as well, it grew at about 32% so continuing to see great growth momentum in our co-working business.Also, for FY27 at this point, I would not like to comment. We will give that guidance in the quarter four results, because we are still planning our annual operating plan there. The sector overall seems extremely bullish. The growth in every sector related to GCCs, as well as if you look at now, even with the Budget, with the AI and the data centre companies, and this solutioning that is going to provide tax holidays is only going to help and improve the sector.Q: You have 152,000 seats, when do we expect this number to double from here?A: So last year, we added about 40,000 seats. This year, our seat addition is about 32,000 and that's specifically because, we are at the highest cycle of the commercial real estate in terms of rentals, so we have been a bit cautious about it. Again, our growth targets remain the same, but we were a bit cautious. So, 32,000 for this year, next year, we will provide that guidance in the next quarter itself.Q: Since you said you are at the highest level of commercial rentals, even volumes and pricing are going in tandem, so I wanted to understand, what would the risk to some of the big opportunities that there are in the industry currently? Would it be pricing decline? Would it be volume decline? How are you seeing the industry shape up going forward since we have seen a big surge already?A: The industry bases a lot of things that have gone in the macro environment, the trade deal happened, the budget was very supportive of foreign investments coming in the GCC boom. I mean, if you look at the GCCs, there are about 2,900 GCCs every quarter. We are adding 25 to 30 new GCCs. Projection is by 2030 we would have close to about 4,500 GCCs employing 2.8 million people from 1.5 million today. So, the growth engines and the drivers for co-working, overall, for commercial real estate, are very strong.For co-working, it's a first port of call, especially for the first time GCCs, they do not have their teams in India, and as a result, co-working and flex provides a great solutioning. Today, we have been able to do 12 GCCs, first time GCCs, 11 more on pipeline. If you look at the overall revenue, 21% of our revenue comes from GCCs, which is about 80 plus companies in our portfolio today. So, very bullish overall, for the sector and as well as for our own growthQ: If you can tell us, how long does it take for a new centre to breakeven? And considering that, 32,000 to 40,000 on an annual basis, do you think next three years we can look at three lakh seats for Awfis?A: We would want to obviously grow in that direction. But I think there is a very clear approach that we are taking where we have to balance the seat addition with the growth and the profitability at the same time.If you look at our numbers, we did about ₹22 crores of PAT at this point, and for the year or nine month period, we are almost ₹50 crores of PAT. For us, balancing the two decent amount of growth, 25-30% while balancing seat addition is very critical. If you look at our even today's seats that we have added, it's enough for us to demonstrate 25 to 30% growth through FY27. Exact guidance we will give, but today we still have seat capacity to fill, which will allow us to grow at that pace.Catch all the stock market live updates hereFollow our live blog for more updates on Q3 results

headline: Emami Q3 Results: Stock jumps over 7% on strong volume growth, dividend declared
condensed_text: Emami Q3 Results: Stock jumps over 7% on strong volume growth, dividend declared. Shares of Emami gained as much as 7% on Wednesday, February 4, in response to its December quarter results, which showed strong volume growth.Emami's volume growth during the quarter stood at 9% from the same period last year.Revenue for the quarter grew nearly 10% year-on-year to ₹1,151.8 crore from ₹1,049.5 crore earlier.Earnings Before Interest, Tax, Depreciation and Amortisation  for the quarter increased to ₹384.2 crore, a growth of 13.4% from the year-ago period.EBITDA margin remained stable at 33.4% from 33.3% last year, while its net profit for the quarter grew by 14.5% year-on-year to ₹319.5 crore from ₹279 crore. The net profit growth for the quarter was despite a ₹10.2 crore impact due to the labour code.Seasonality benefits also reflected in the results for Emami as Winter accounts for 60% of the company's sales.The board of Emami also declared a dividend of ₹6 per share, the record date for which has been fixed as February 10, 2026.Shares of Emami are now trading 4.8% higher after the results announcement at ₹506.4. The stock is down 13% in the last 12 months.

The stock is down 13% in the last 12 months.

headline: RITES Q3 Results: Revenue up 6%, margin expands; dividend announced
condensed_text: RITES Q3 Results: Revenue up 6%, margin expands; dividend announced. RITES Ltd posted a steady performance for the December quarter, reporting a 2% year-on-year rise in net profit to ₹102 crore, compared with ₹100 crore in the corresponding period last year.Revenue increased 5.7% to ₹608.6 crore, supported by stable execution across its core consultancy and project management segments.Operating performance improved meaningfully during the quarter, with EBITDA rising 21.5% year-on-year to ₹142.5 crore from ₹117.3 crore.This led to a notable expansion in margins, which stood at 23.4%, compared with 20.4% a year earlier, reflecting better operating leverage.Alongside the earnings announcement, the company declared its third interim dividend for FY26 at ₹1.90 per equity share, representing 19% of the paid-up share capital. The record date for determining eligible shareholders has been fixed as February 10, 2026, with the dividend scheduled to be paid on or before March 5, 2026.Also Read: Tube Investments Q3 Results: Profit jumps 18%, margin expands; dividend declaredIn the equity market, shares of RITES were trading at ₹226.26 on the NSE as of 2:31 pm, up 1.09% for the day. The stock touched an intraday high of ₹229.67 following the results announcement, as investors took note of the improvement in operating profitability and the dividend payout.
full_content: RITES Ltd posted a steady performance for the December quarter, reporting a 2% year-on-year rise in net profit to ₹102 crore, compared with ₹100 crore in the corresponding period last year.Revenue increased 5.7% to ₹608.6 crore, supported by stable execution across its core consultancy and project management segments.Operating performance improved meaningfully during the quarter, with EBITDA rising 21.5% year-on-year to ₹142.5 crore from ₹117.3 crore.This led to a notable expansion in margins, which stood at 23.4%, compared with 20.4% a year earlier, reflecting better operating leverage.Alongside the earnings announcement, the company declared its third interim dividend for FY26 at ₹1.90 per equity share, representing 19% of the paid-up share capital. The record date for determining eligible shareholders has been fixed as February 10, 2026, with the dividend scheduled to be paid on or before March 5, 2026.Also Read: Tube Investments Q3 Results: Profit jumps 18%, margin expands; dividend declaredIn the equity market, shares of RITES were trading at ₹226.26 on the NSE as of 2:31 pm, up 1.09% for the day. The stock touched an intraday high of ₹229.67 following the results announcement, as investors took note of the improvement in operating profitability and the dividend payout.

headline: Trident, JK Tyres, SRF among top beneficiaries of twin trade deals; tailwinds for exports
condensed_text: The dual agreements—described as "the India-EU Free Trade Agreement (the Mother of all deals) and the India-US Trade Deal (the 'Father of all deals')—have fundamentally altered India's trade structure. The India-US trade deal took a positive step, with the US reducing the tariff on India’s exports to 18 per cent and doing away with the penal tariff of 25 per cent, said Kotak Institutional Equities, with expecting markets to react positively with some near-term appreciation bias for the Indian rupee on the back of positive sentiments and flows. While details are awaited, reports suggest that India will have to remove their tariff and non-tariff barriers, commit to more imports from the US in addition to the current levels and stop buying Russian crude oil," it added. Ventura Securities has picked Gokaldas Exports, Welspun Living, Indo Count Industries, KPR Mills, Trident, Arvind, Vardhman Textiles, Bharat Forge, Samvardhana Motherson International, Sona Comstar, Sundaram Finance, Balkrishna Industries, JK Tyres, Avanti Feeds, Apex Frozen Waterbase, Sky Gold, Vaibhav Global, Goldiam International as key beneficiaries of the trade deal . It also sees Aarti Industries, Vinati Organics, SRF, Navin Fluorine, Gujarat Fluorochemicals, PI Industries, Mirza International, Mayur Uniquoters, Superhouse and Bhartiya International as other key beneficiaries .
full_content:
India's recent tariff relief from the United States (US) has strengthened the country's role in global exports, closely following the finalisation of the European trade agreement. The India-US trade deal is expected to drive substantial growth for Indian exports, especially in sectors like textiles, apparel, and electronics, as Ventura Securities highlights.
The dual agreements—described as "the India-EU Free Trade Agreement (the Mother of all deals) and the India-US Trade Deal (the 'Father of all deals')—have fundamentally altered India's trade structure. For sectors with high export dependence, such as textiles, chemicals, and auto ancillaries, the changes signal immediate margin improvements and long-term opportunities.
The India-US trade deal took a positive step, with the US reducing the tariff on India’s exports to 18 per cent and doing away with the penal tariff of 25 per cent, said Kotak Institutional Equities, with expecting markets to react positively with some near-term appreciation bias for the Indian rupee on the back of positive sentiments and flows.
While details are awaited, reports suggest that India will have to remove their tariff and non-tariff barriers, commit to more imports from the US in addition to the current levels and stop buying Russian crude oil," it added. "Indian producers or tariff rates are relatively low, though some risks remain for auto parts, iron/steel, plastics and chemicals."
According to Ventura Securities, this development brings a competitive 18% reciprocal tariff with the US—which effectively scraps the 25% 'Russian oil penalty'—and achieving zero duty access for 99% of exports to the EU. This positions India as a favoured alternative to Chinese and Southeast Asian supply chains.
Ventura Securities notes that most key players are already operating at 75–90% capacity utilisation, and with reduced trade barriers, the industry is likely to enter a significant 'Brownfield' expansion phase. Export-dependent companies are expected to benefit most from tariff relief, particularly those with substantial US market exposure.
Major competitors remain leading Chinese and Southeast Asian firms, but the new deals may shift the competitive landscape in favour of Indian producers. Ventura Securities observes that the current environment is set for substantial expansion across export-driven segments, as regulatory changes and improved market access begin to influence company strategies and sector returns.
Ventura Securities has picked Gokaldas Exports, Welspun Living, Indo Count Industries, KPR Mills, Trident, Arvind, Vardhman Textiles, Bharat Forge, Samvardhana Motherson International, Sona Comstar, Sundaram Finance, Balkrishna Industries, JK Tyres, Avanti Feeds, Apex Frozen Waterbase, Sky Gold, Vaibhav Global, Goldiam International as key beneficiaries of the trade deal .
It also sees Aarti Industries, Vinati Organics, SRF, Navin Fluorine, Gujarat Fluorochemicals, PI Industries, Mirza International, Mayur Uniquoters, Superhouse and Bhartiya International as other key beneficiaries . All these companies have up to 90 per cent experts to the US or European nations.

headline: ONGC, Oil India, IOC, HPCL, BPCL shares gain up to 7%; here's what analysts say
condensed_text: Indian Oil Corporation ( IOC ) was up 3.10% to Rs 172.75, while Hindustan Petroleum Corporation (HPCL) climbed to Rs 461.10, gaining 2.24%. “Brent crude has seen a modest uptick amid renewed geopolitical noise in the Middle East, yet it remains comfortably in the moderate $65–70 range and lower than earlier peaks,” Jain said. Jain said that the current movement in OMC stocks like BPCL, HPCL, and IOC is a result of the market digesting the strong tailwinds from the earlier drop in crude prices, which delivered materially higher gross refining margins and robust profitability in Q3FY2026. “That earnings strength, combined with a healthy rebound in petroleum product volumes driven by seasonal demand and economic pickup, plus the welcome absence of any excise duty hike in the recent Budget, has removed a major overhang and kept investor sentiment supportive,” Jain added. “From a structural perspective, the previous breakout zone near 350–355 now acts as a key support base,” Shah explains, adding that as long as the price holds this region, the structure remains valid for a potential move toward the “395–420 target zone,” he added.
full_content:
Shares of oil exploration & production stocks such as Oil India, ONGC and others climbed on Wednesday, rising as much as 7% in early trade. At the last check on the BSE, Oil India led the gains, rising 6.63% to Rs 521.10.
It was followed closely by Oil and Natural Gas Corporation (ONGC), which rose to Rs 269, a gain of 4.63%.
Indian Oil Corporation ( IOC ) was up 3.10% to Rs 172.75, while Hindustan Petroleum Corporation (HPCL) climbed to Rs 461.10, gaining 2.24%. Bharat Petroleum Corporation ( BPCL ) is also in green with a 2.02% gain at Rs 380.80.
The broader BSE Oil & Gas index was up 2.21% to 28,980.02.
Saurabh Jain, Head of Fundamental Research at SMC Global Securities, pointed out that while geopolitical tensions linger, the market dynamics remain supportive for downstream players.
“Brent crude has seen a modest uptick amid renewed geopolitical noise in the Middle East, yet it remains comfortably in the moderate $65–70 range and lower than earlier peaks,” Jain said.
Jain said that the current movement in OMC stocks like BPCL, HPCL, and IOC is a result of the market digesting the strong tailwinds from the earlier drop in crude prices, which delivered materially higher gross refining margins and robust profitability in Q3FY2026.
“That earnings strength, combined with a healthy rebound in petroleum product volumes driven by seasonal demand and economic pickup, plus the welcome absence of any excise duty hike in the recent Budget, has removed a major overhang and kept investor sentiment supportive,” Jain added.
Jain noted that downstream players are simply benefiting from the current stable-to-moderate crude environment through improved refining cracks and marketing spreads, allowing OMCs to maintain positive momentum even as oil inches higher. “The rally looks set to continue as long as crude doesn’t spike sharply; Middle East escalation remains the primary risk to watch,” he added.
Oil India is displaying a strong bullish continuation structure on the daily chart, with price breaking out to fresh 52-week highs, said Aakash Shah, Technical Research Analyst at Choice Equity Broking.
For Oil India stock, the consolidation zone around 480–490 is a key support, with the setup favouring further upside toward the 540–560 target zone in the near term, Shah said.
For ONGC, Shah noted a sharp bullish breakout from its recent consolidation range, supported by rising volumes. The stock has reclaimed its 20 and 50 EMAs, indicating a shift in momentum in favour of buyers.
“Structurally, for ONGC stock the breakout zone around 250–255 now acts as an important demand area. Sustained holding above this zone keeps the bullish structure intact and opens the door for further upside toward the 280–290 target zone,” Shah said.
Meanwhile, BPCL is exhibiting “strong relative strength, with price trading near all-time highs,” according to Shah. “From a structural perspective, the previous breakout zone near 350–355 now acts as a key support base,” Shah explains, adding that as long as the price holds this region, the structure remains valid for a potential move toward the “395–420 target zone,” he added.
Copyright © 2026 Living Media India Limited. For reprint rights: Syndications Today. India Today Group.

headline: BHEL bags over ₹1,000 cr project from Hindalco Industries
condensed_text:
(representative image)  The scope of work includes design, engineering, manufacture, supply up to site, unloading & storage, erection, commissioning and performance guarantee test for 2 x 150 megawatt BTG (boiler, turbine, and generator) package excluding civil work. VIJAYA BHASKAR CH
State-owned BHEL on Wednesday said it has secured an order in the range of ₹1,200-1,500 crore from Hindalco Industries. The scope of work includes design, engineering, manufacture, supply up to site, unloading & storage, erection, commissioning and performance guarantee test for 2 x 150 megawatt BTG (boiler, turbine, and generator) package excluding civil work. Under Ministry of Heavy Industries, BHEL is one of India's largest engineering and manufacturing enterprises in the energy and infrastructure sectors, and a leading power equipment manufacturer globally. The company provides a comprehensive portfolio of products, systems and services to players in power, transmission, transportation, renewables, water, defence & aerospace, oil & gas, among others.
full_content:
(representative image)  The scope of work includes design, engineering, manufacture, supply up to site, unloading & storage, erection, commissioning and performance guarantee test for 2 x 150 megawatt BTG (boiler, turbine, and generator) package excluding civil work.
VIJAYA BHASKAR CH
State-owned BHEL on Wednesday said it has secured an order in the range of ₹1,200-1,500 crore from Hindalco Industries.
BHEL said a letter of intent (LOI) in this regard has been received from Aditya Aluminium, Hindalco Industries.
The scope of work includes design, engineering, manufacture, supply up to site, unloading & storage, erection, commissioning and performance guarantee test for 2 x 150 megawatt BTG (boiler, turbine, and generator) package excluding civil work.
The project is to be executed at Lapanga, Sambalpur in Odisha in a span of about 3 years, BHEL said in a regulatory filing.
Under Ministry of Heavy Industries, BHEL is one of India's largest engineering and manufacturing enterprises in the energy and infrastructure sectors, and a leading power equipment manufacturer globally.
The company provides a comprehensive portfolio of products, systems and services to players in power, transmission, transportation, renewables, water, defence & aerospace, oil & gas, among others.
Published on  February 4, 2026

The company provides a comprehensive portfolio of products, systems and services to players in power, transmission, transportation, renewables, water, defence & aerospace, oil & gas, among others.
full_content:
(representative image)  The scope of work includes design, engineering, manufacture, supply up to site, unloading & storage, erection, commissioning and performance guarantee test for 2 x 150 megawatt BTG (boiler, turbine, and generator) package excluding civil work.
VIJAYA BHASKAR CH
State-owned BHEL on Wednesday said it has secured an order in the range of ₹1,200-1,500 crore from Hindalco Industries.
BHEL said a letter of intent (LOI) in this regard has been received from Aditya Aluminium, Hindalco Industries.
The scope of work includes design, engineering, manufacture, supply up to site, unloading & storage, erection, commissioning and performance guarantee test for 2 x 150 megawatt BTG (boiler, turbine, and generator) package excluding civil work.
The project is to be executed at Lapanga, Sambalpur in Odisha in a span of about 3 years, BHEL said in a regulatory filing.
Under Ministry of Heavy Industries, BHEL is one of India's largest engineering and manufacturing enterprises in the energy and infrastructure sectors, and a leading power equipment manufacturer globally.
The company provides a comprehensive portfolio of products, systems and services to players in power, transmission, transportation, renewables, water, defence & aerospace, oil & gas, among others.
Published on  February 4, 2026

Major projects remain on track, with revised completion timelines as follows: Kochi polypropylene plant by CY28, Bina refinery/petchem expansion by midCY28, and Andhra Pradesh (AP) refinery/petrochem project awaiting DFR finalization. full_content:
Prabhudas Lilladher's research report onBharat Petroleum Corporation
Major projects remain on track, with revised completion timelines as follows: Kochi polypropylene plant by CY28, Bina refinery/petchem expansion by midCY28, and Andhra Pradesh (AP) refinery/petrochem project awaiting DFR finalization. Total cost for the AP project may be revised upward to Rs1,100– 1,200bn from Rs960bn, due to rupee depreciation. The AP refinery will be housed under a separate entity, with BPCL exploring a strategic partnership, including discussions with foreign partners; Oil India has already signed a nonbinding MoU for participation in the project. BPCL’s cumulative capex over the next 5 years is guided at Rs2,500–2,700bn. Annual capex is expected to be Rs200-250bn over the initial 2 years, ramping up to Rs500-600bn p.a. over the subsequent 3 years. Further, BPCL continues to source non-sanctioned Russian crude, in the absence of any formal communication from the ministry. Additionally, if given the opportunity to purchase Venezuelan crude, BPCL will first test its feasibility/combability with the pipelines and refinery. Subject to successful trials, the company may proceed with commercial sourcing, with expected discount of ~USD9/bbl to benchmark.
Outlook
We value the stock at 1.6x Dec’27E P/BV (previous: 1.5x) and maintain ‘Accumulate’ rating with revised TP of Rs406 (previous Rs381).

headline: Tata Motors PV Q3 Preview: JLR hit to weigh on profits; revenue may slip up to 9% despite festive, GST tailwinds
condensed_text: Auto major Tata Motors Passenger Vehicles (TMPV) Q3 performance is expected to show a sharp divergence between its India passenger vehicle (PV) business and its global luxury arm, Jaguar Land Rover (JLR). While Nuvama Institutional Equities, YES Securities and JM Financial see net losses up in Q3FY26 to Rs 4,549 crore, Deven Choksey Research expects 18% year-over-year net profit growth. Here's what brokerage estimates say on these 5 key parameters: 1) PAT -- Nuvama Institutional Equities expects adjusted net losses of Rs 3,701 crore largely reflecting the impact of weaker JLR profitability. 4) EBITDA margin -- Nuvama expects EBITDA margin to compress sharply to 0.5%, down 1,275 bps YoY and 248 bps QoQ, led by weak JLR scale and higher costs. 5) Volume Deven Choksey Research estimates PV volumes at 3,60,472 units, up 6% YoY and a sharp 71.2% QoQ, supported by festive demand, GST 2.0-led revival and launches such as the Sierra.
full_content: Auto major Tata Motors Passenger Vehicles (TMPV) Q3 performance is expected to show a sharp divergence between its India passenger vehicle (PV) business and its global luxury arm, Jaguar Land Rover (JLR). While domestic PV volumes are seen holding up on festive demand and recent launches, consolidated earnings are likely to remain under pressure due to a production hit and margin stress at JLR following a cyber-attack incident. Brokerages broadly expect weak consolidated profitability, with losses in some estimates, even as India PV trends remain comparatively steady. While Nuvama Institutional Equities, YES Securities and JM Financial see net losses up in Q3FY26 to Rs 4,549 crore, Deven Choksey Research expects 18% year-over-year net profit growth. Revenue may drop up to 9%, highest among its peers. The company will announce its earnings on Thursday, February 5. Here's what brokerage estimates say on these 5 key parameters: 1) PAT -- Nuvama Institutional Equities expects adjusted net losses of Rs 3,701 crore largely reflecting the impact of weaker JLR profitability. Live Events -- YES Securities pegs the net loss at Rs 2,208 crore weighed down by sharp YoY decline in JLR earnings. -- JM Financial is the most cautious, forecasting net losses of Rs 4,549 crore. -- Deven Choksey Research is the only brokerage among the four which estimates TMPV to report a profit, albeit 18% lower on YoY basis at Rs 446 crore. 2) Revenues -- Nuvama estimates consolidated revenues at Rs 69,023 crore, down 27% YoY and 5% QoQ, as JLR production disruptions offset robust India PV growth. -- YES Securities sees revenue at Rs 68,447 crore, down 5.4% QoQ, with a steep YoY decline driven by JLR. -- JM Financial expects revenues of Rs 67,094 crore, down 29% YoY and 8.3% QoQ. -- Deven Choksey Research pegs PV revenues at Rs 10,218 crore, down 9.3% YoY and 41.2% QoQ. 3) EBITDA Nuvama forecasts EBITDA of just Rs 374 crore, down 97% YoY, citing higher variable marketing expenses (VME) and lower operating leverage at JLR. -- YES Securities estimates EBITDA at Rs 1,490 crore, with partial recovery in margins QoQ. -- JM Financial expects EBITDA losses of Rs 794 crore, reflecting continued stress at JLR. -- Deven Choksey Research estimates PV EBITDA at Rs 1,174 crore, down 5.4% YoY. 4) EBITDA margin -- Nuvama expects EBITDA margin to compress sharply to 0.5%, down 1,275 bps YoY and 248 bps QoQ, led by weak JLR scale and higher costs. -- YES Securities sees consolidated EBITDA margins recovering modestly to around 2.2%, though still well below historical levels due to JLR headwinds. 5) Volume Deven Choksey Research estimates PV volumes at 3,60,472 units, up 6% YoY and a sharp 71.2% QoQ, supported by festive demand, GST 2.0-led revival and launches such as the Sierra. 6) Key monitorables JLR demand and production outlook post the cyber-attack disruption remains key monitorables, said both Nuvama and JM Financial. Meanwhile, margin recovery trajectory at JLR, including the pace of volume ramp-up and VME normalization also remain in focus, opines YES Securities. (Disclaimer: The recommendations, suggestions, views, and opinions given by the experts are their own. These do not represent the views of The Economic Times.) headline: TeamLease Q3 Results: Shares rise as profit climbs 47%; specialised staffing revenue up 30%
condensed_text: TeamLease Q3 Results: Shares rise as profit climbs 47%; specialised staffing revenue up 30%. TeamLease Services Ltd, one of India’s largest staffing companies, announced its Q3FY26 results on Wednesday, reporting a mixed performance marked by lower profit but improved operating metrics.Net profit rose 46.8% year-on-year to ₹41.7 crore, supported by margin expansion and operating leverage, even as revenue grew a modest 3% to ₹3,013 crore.EBITDA increased 22% to ₹42.4 crore, up from ₹34.8 crore a year ago, leading to a margin expansion to 1.4% from 1.2%.Operationally, TeamLease added 107 new logos during the quarter. In General Staffing, 22 new logos were added, with over 55% under the variable model, while 20% of gross associates hired were first-time job seekers.Specialised Staffing continued to perform well, with revenue growing 30% year-on-year, supported by strong traction from global capability centres , which contributed over 65% of segment revenue.The company saw a reduction of around 27,000 associates during the quarter, largely due to insourcing by BFSI clients, impacting both General Staffing and the Degree Apprenticeship segments. Headcount in General Staffing declined 7% sequentially, while Degree Apprenticeship was similarly affected by BFSI-led insourcing.During the quarter, the company received an income tax refund of ₹106.1 crore for AY 2024–25, including interest of ₹10.1 crore, taking net free cash to ₹430 crore.Commenting on the performance, Executive Vice Chairman Ashok Reddy said the company’s focus on digitisation and cost optimisation continues to drive operating leverage, adding that the full impact of BFSI headcount losses is expected to be absorbed by Q1FY27.Following the earnings announcement, shares of TeamLease Services surged to an intraday high of ₹1,594.80., up over 8%. As of 3:16 pm, the stock was trading 1,479.20, up 3.7% on NSE.

In General Staffing, 22 new logos were added, with over 55% under the variable model, while 20% of gross associates hired were first-time job seekers.Specialised Staffing continued to perform well, with revenue growing 30% year-on-year, supported by strong traction from global capability centres , which contributed over 65% of segment revenue.The company saw a reduction of around 27,000 associates during the quarter, largely due to insourcing by BFSI clients, impacting both General Staffing and the Degree Apprenticeship segments. Headcount in General Staffing declined 7% sequentially, while Degree Apprenticeship was similarly affected by BFSI-led insourcing.During the quarter, the company received an income tax refund of ₹106.1 crore for AY 2024–25, including interest of ₹10.1 crore, taking net free cash to ₹430 crore.Commenting on the performance, Executive Vice Chairman Ashok Reddy said the company’s focus on digitisation and cost optimisation continues to drive operating leverage, adding that the full impact of BFSI headcount losses is expected to be absorbed by Q1FY27.Following the earnings announcement, shares of TeamLease Services surged to an intraday high of ₹1,594.80., up over 8%. headline: Carysil shares jump over 5% as Q3 profit surges 68% on margin expansion
condensed_text: Carysil shares jump over 5% as Q3 profit surges 68% on margin expansion. Shares of Carysil Limited rose more than 5% after the company reported a strong set of earnings for the December quarter, with net profit jumping 68% year-on-year to ₹21 crore, aided by operating leverage and margin expansion, despite modest revenue growth.In an exchange filing on Wednesday, February 4, Carysil said revenue from operations rose 9.6% YoY to ₹222.6 crore in Q3FY26, compared with ₹203 crore in the same quarter last year. EBITDA surged 46.2% YoY to ₹42 crore from ₹28.8 crore, while EBITDA margin expanded sharply to 18.9% from 14.2% a year ago.The improvement in profitability was driven by better cost efficiencies and operating leverage, with margins expanding even as topline growth remained in single digits.Read more: Emcure Pharma Q3 Results: Strong operating performance but stock gives up gainsSeparately, the company informed exchanges that ICRA, the monitoring agency appointed for its Qualified Institutions Placement , reported no material deviation in the utilisation of funds raised through the issue. Carysil had raised ₹125 crore via the QIP in July 2024, with net proceeds of ₹121.65 crore after issue-related expenses.As of December 31, 2025, the company had utilised ₹82.52 crore of the QIP proceeds, primarily towards capital expenditure for new manufacturing facilities, working capital requirements and general corporate purposes. The remaining unutilised amount of ₹39.13 crore has been parked in fixed deposits and cash credit accounts, as per the monitoring report.ICRA noted that the utilisation of funds remains in line with the stated objects of the issue and that there were no delays or adverse events impacting the execution of the company’s expansion plans.Shares of the company surged over 5% following the Q3 result announcement and were trading at ₹1,006.80 as of 3.12 pm.

EBITDA surged 46.2% YoY to ₹42 crore from ₹28.8 crore, while EBITDA margin expanded sharply to 18.9% from 14.2% a year ago.The improvement in profitability was driven by better cost efficiencies and operating leverage, with margins expanding even as topline growth remained in single digits.Read more: Emcure Pharma Q3 Results: Strong operating performance but stock gives up gainsSeparately, the company informed exchanges that ICRA, the monitoring agency appointed for its Qualified Institutions Placement , reported no material deviation in the utilisation of funds raised through the issue. Carysil had raised ₹125 crore via the QIP in July 2024, with net proceeds of ₹121.65 crore after issue-related expenses.As of December 31, 2025, the company had utilised ₹82.52 crore of the QIP proceeds, primarily towards capital expenditure for new manufacturing facilities, working capital requirements and general corporate purposes. The remaining unutilised amount of ₹39.13 crore has been parked in fixed deposits and cash credit accounts, as per the monitoring report.ICRA noted that the utilisation of funds remains in line with the stated objects of the issue and that there were no delays or adverse events impacting the execution of the company’s expansion plans.Shares of the company surged over 5% following the Q3 result announcement and were trading at ₹1,006.80 as of 3.12 pm. headline: RITES Q3 earnings: Net profit rises to Rs 109 crore; board declares interim dividend
condensed_text: Net profit rose 5% to Rs 115.10 crore in the last quarter against Rs 109.39 crore in the year ago period. Revenue from operations came at Rs 608 crore in the l;ast quarter against the previous close of Rs 223.80. EBITDA rose 21.5% to Rs 142.5 crore in Q3 against Rs 117.3 crore in the year ago period. In other updates, the firm said its board declared an interim dividend of Rs 1.90 for the Financial Year 2025-26. The record date set for the purpose of payment of third interim dividend for Financial Year 2025-26 is Tuesday, February 10, 2026.
full_content:
Shares of RITES rose over 2% on Wednesday after the firm reported its Q3 earnings. Net profit rose 5% to Rs 115.10 crore in the last quarter against Rs 109.39 crore in the year ago period. Revenue from operations came at Rs 608 crore in the l;ast quarter against the previous close of Rs 223.80.
EBITDA rose 21.5% to Rs 142.5 crore in Q3 against Rs 117.3 crore in the year ago period.
EBITDA margins came at 23.4% in Q3 from 20.4% on a year to year basis.
RITES stock gained 2.41% to Rs 229.20 on Wednesday. Market cap of the firm stood at Rs 10,866 crore. Total 0.91 lakh shares changed hands amounting to a turnover of Rs 2.05 crore.
In other updates, the firm said its board declared an interim dividend of Rs 1.90 for the Financial Year 2025-26. The record date set for the purpose of payment of third interim dividend for Financial Year 2025-26 is Tuesday, February 10, 2026. The dividend shall be paid on or before March 5, 2026.

headline: Emcure Pharma Q3 net profit rises 48% YoY at ₹231 cr
condensed_text: Emcure Pharmaceuticals on Wednesday posted a 48 per cent year-on-year increase in its consolidated profit after tax at ₹231 crore for the third quarter ended December 31, 2025, led by robust sales growth in business verticals. Revenue from operations increased to ₹2,363 crore for the period under review as against ₹1,963 crore in the year-ago period, Emcure Pharmaceuticals said in a statement. Emcure Pharmaceuticals CEO and MD Satish Mehta said Q3 delivered a strong performance, with all its businesses outpacing industry growth. The company’s focus remains on improving profitability even as it continues to invest in people, products and processes to drive strong growth, he added. "The Novo Nordisk partnership has given Emcure an early-entry advantage, positioning us well in the fast-growing obesity segment.
full_content:
Emcure Pharmaceuticals on Wednesday posted a 48 per cent year-on-year increase in its consolidated profit after tax at ₹231 crore for the third quarter ended December 31, 2025, led by robust sales growth in business verticals.
The drug firm reported a Profit After Tax (PAT) of ₹156 crore for the October-December period of last fiscal.
Revenue from operations increased to ₹2,363 crore for the period under review as against ₹1,963 crore in the year-ago period, Emcure Pharmaceuticals said in a statement.
Emcure Pharmaceuticals CEO and MD Satish Mehta said Q3 delivered a strong performance, with all its businesses outpacing industry growth.
The company’s focus remains on improving profitability even as it continues to invest in people, products and processes to drive strong growth, he added.
"The Novo Nordisk partnership has given Emcure an early-entry advantage, positioning us well in the fast-growing obesity segment. We remain focused on delivering strong growth along with margin improvement,” Mehta stated.
Emcure shares were trading 0.94 per cent up at ₹1,519.85 apiece on BSE.
Published on  February 4, 2026
