headline: Nykaa share price jumps over 6% to 1-year high high after Q3 earnings
condensed_text: FSN E-Commerce Ventures , the parent of Indian beauty retailer Nykaa, saw its shares surge another 6.2% in Friday’s trade on February 6, hitting a 1-year high of ₹ 274.45 apiece. According to CNBC TV18 , Japanese brokerage firm Nomura upgraded Nykaa to a 'buy' from ‘hold’ and raised its price target to ₹ 305 from ₹ 261 earlier, implying an upside potential of 17% from Thursday’s closing price. It posted a 27% rise in consolidated revenue from core operations to ₹ 2,873 crore over the corresponding period last year, while the EBITDA stood at ₹ 230 crore, a 63% year-on-year jump, with margins expanding 180 basis points to 8% in Q3. The performance was boosted by strong demand for skincare and makeup products, with revenue from the beauty segment jumping 27% year-on-year to ₹ 2,622 crore in the December quarter, its filing showed. Nykaa reported a 26% jump in annual unique transacting customers (AUTC) in the beauty segment to 18.7 million customers and a 33% increase to 4.1 million customers in the fashion vertical.
full_content:
FSN E-Commerce Ventures , the parent of Indian beauty retailer Nykaa, saw its shares surge another 6.2% in Friday’s trade on February 6, hitting a 1-year high of ₹ 274.45 apiece. This extended the stock’s winning run to a fourth straight session, as brokerages stayed bullish on the stock following the company’s better-than-expected performance in the December-ending quarter.
According to CNBC TV18 , Japanese brokerage firm Nomura upgraded Nykaa to a 'buy' from ‘hold’ and raised its price target to ₹ 305 from ₹ 261 earlier, implying an upside potential of 17% from Thursday’s closing price. Mint could not independently verify this report.
The brokerage expects the company’s EBITDA to sustain a compounded annual growth rate (CAGR) of over 25%, even after growing at a 45% CAGR in the past.
Meanwhile, domestic brokerage JM Financial also maintained its bullish stance on the stock, retaining its ‘buy’ rating with a target price of ₹ 325 apiece, signalling an upside potential of 25.8%.
The brokerage said Nykaa has delivered against the odds by improving margins while continuing to post industry-leading growth across segments. Going forward, it expects lower marketing spending and strong operating leverage to support profitability.
It expects the company to sustain growth momentum, with higher BPC profits gradually offsetting losses in eB2B, while the fashion segment is expected to turn profitable in FY26 itself.
JM Financial added that Nykaa remains one of the most sustainable compounding stories in the Indian internet space.
The company reported a consolidated net profit of ₹ 68 crore in Q3FY26 , a 157% YoY jump, according to its consolidated financial statements filed on Thursday.
It posted a 27% rise in consolidated revenue from core operations to ₹ 2,873 crore over the corresponding period last year, while the EBITDA stood at ₹ 230 crore, a 63% year-on-year jump, with margins expanding 180 basis points to 8% in Q3.
The performance was boosted by strong demand for skincare and makeup products, with revenue from the beauty segment jumping 27% year-on-year to ₹ 2,622 crore in the December quarter, its filing showed.
The company achieved its highest-ever quarterly consolidated GMV of ₹ 5,795 crore in the December quarter, representing a 28% year-on-year increase, according to the company's earnings filing.
Nykaa reported a 26% jump in annual unique transacting customers (AUTC) in the beauty segment to 18.7 million customers and a 33% increase to 4.1 million customers in the fashion vertical. Total orders in the quarter grew to 3 million, up 39% year on year.

headline: Kaynes Technology reaffirms FY28 $1 bn sales target despite Q3 miss
condensed_text: Kaynes Technology has said it will continue to target $1 billion in revenue by the financial year 2027-28 , despite reporting October-December 2025 quarter results that came in below analyst estimates.CFO Jairam Sampath said the company’s long-term growth strategy remains linked to building an integrated electronics manufacturing platform. And, there are these quarterly numbers that are expected, despite a three-quarter growth of 37%, people do expect more, which I take as a positive sign, because I think it means that the public, the investors and customers, everybody is asking us to realise our potential.Fundamentally, this year, we will do about ₹1,700 crore in the fourth quarter, so that we can take up the quarterly number to about ₹4,100 crore. So, let's see where it lands.Q: Operating cash flows will be positive, right, when we reach the end of this fiscal year, correct?A: Absolutely.Also Read | 'I think market is making a mistake' — ICICI Pru AMC Co-CIO on why he avoids EMS companiesQ: What about the semiconductor facility that's expected?A: It will start this year. But I'm not able to commit numbers there yet, and that will be in addition to this ₹4,100 crore that we are talking about, which is our traditional - out of ₹4,400 crore, we had talked about ₹100 crore of revenues in the semiconductor area.I want to bring a very important distinction here. So, going forward, $1 billion and $2 billion numbers, etc., will become more of a reality.Q: $1 billion by 2028, that's on, right?A: That's on.Q: A lot of sell-side analysts, all of last evening, were saying that maybe Kaynes Technologies had given some kind of hint that Q3 is going to be sort of a washout.
full_content: Kaynes Technology has said it will continue to target $1 billion in revenue by the financial year 2027-28 , despite reporting October-December 2025 quarter results that came in below analyst estimates.CFO Jairam Sampath said the company’s long-term growth strategy remains linked to building an integrated electronics manufacturing platform."We've always been talking about us being an integrated company, an end-to-end company," Sampath said.He added that scale benefits from this model are expected to support long-term revenue expansion. "So, going forward, $1 billion and $2 billion numbers, etc., will become more of a reality," he added.The company continues to focus on expanding its electronics manufacturing services  and related capabilities as part of its long-term roadmap. Management has maintained that new business verticals and capacity additions are expected to support growth over the next few years.Kaynes has been investing in semiconductor and PCB manufacturing capabilities as part of its strategy to build a full-stack electronics manufacturing ecosystem. The company expects these investments to contribute to revenue growth over time, alongside its existing EMS business.The company reported its results for the October–December 2025 quarter on Wednesday, February 5, missing analyst expectations across key financial parameters.The company’s shares have declined more than 18% over the last year. Kaynes Technology currently has a market capitalisation of ₹22,792.12 crore.These are the edited excerpts of the interview.Q: The Street will be a little bit disappointed, because there was no hint of this sort of a howler coming in. So, clarify a couple of aspects. First, in Q3, was there some kind of one-off there? Was there some kind of revenue that hasn't been reflected that will get reflected in Q4? And also, what is the revised guidance for FY26, because it appears now that it's a very tall ask; you have only done 55% of what you promised.A: Fundamentally, the business, ironically, is poised at its best at this point. And, there are these quarterly numbers that are expected, despite a three-quarter growth of 37%, people do expect more, which I take as a positive sign, because I think it means that the public, the investors and customers, everybody is asking us to realise our potential.Fundamentally, this year, we will do about ₹1,700 crore in the fourth quarter, so that we can take up the quarterly number to about ₹4,100 crore. And this is without adding a particular product that we have developed for the railways, and a new version is being created for that. So that is a postponement for about ₹300 crore of business.Q: You said to do ₹4,100 crore for what period?A: For this FY26.Q: That is against what you said earlier?A: ₹4,400 crore was on a consolidated basis. This is primarily all the revenues have come in from the EMS sector. We are still tentative about the option chain  numbers being anything significant this year, so we will let it play out.Also Read | Kaynes Technology’s Japan partnerships mark next step in semiconductor strategy: CFOQ: What about margins? They're at 14.8. What happens here? They are about 100–150 basis points lower than what the street expected. What happens to margins?A: Margins will be around 16%. We did have a small expense out of the Labour Code change. Other than that, this year we will deliver about 16% on the EBITDA number, and the profit after tax  number will be two-digit. I don't think we will miss out on these two numbers, and for the quarter revenue number, it is about ₹1,700 crore, what we are planning. We have already completed one month and are quite confident that we'll deliver this number.Q: Is there any number on consolidated revenues for FY26 and also on working capital days, that have spiked up to 139 days? What led to that and what will it come down to by the end of Q4?A: I will answer the related question too, which will be the follow-up question. See, fundamentally, people are looking forward to us implementing all our capexes early and then making sure that we are operating cash positive. We came very close to being operating cash positive on a standalone basis in the parent company, that is, KPIL. We just had about ₹55 crore of negative cash flow at the operating level. But at the end of the year, the operating cash flows for the consolidated number will be significantly positive. That's point number one.And this is possible because we will most probably improve the inventory portion of our working capital, because the inventory has kind of gone up a little bit because of the delayed execution of certain orders and so on. We are taking stock of the entire situation and are hopeful that we will be able to deliver on the working capital number, which last year stood at about 85 days. So, this year, we are saying 70–85 days, somewhere in between there, and we have another two months to go. So, let's see where it lands.Q: Operating cash flows will be positive, right, when we reach the end of this fiscal year, correct?A: Absolutely.Also Read | 'I think market is making a mistake' — ICICI Pru AMC Co-CIO on why he avoids EMS companiesQ: What about the semiconductor facility that's expected?A: It will start this year. We have started commercial production. Our fiscal support agreement has been signed. It's important to know that, of the three clients that we have onboarded, we have already started working on the second client. We were the first to ship out the chipset. So, it takes a little bit of time. Sometimes, we probably overestimated our ability to get this done the first time, but still, it is the best in the industry as of now. Among all four peer group companies, we are the only ones to have exported India-assembled products.So, the primary plant, which is going to do the series production, is almost ready, and hopefully, we will have something on board. But I'm not able to commit numbers there yet, and that will be in addition to this ₹4,100 crore that we are talking about, which is our traditional - out of ₹4,400 crore, we had talked about ₹100 crore of revenues in the semiconductor area.I want to bring a very important distinction here. I know there are questions that people ask about other things, but our PCB facility has almost come up fully. With PCB investment, it was about ₹1,400 crore; and this ₹1,400 crore, we had not invested to just get ₹1,400 crore of the bare PCB business. We had also invested with an eye on the EMS, which subsequently can be done, because when we join early with the customers, about ₹15,000 crore of potential EMS is there, which is probably unnoticed by people. We have always been talking about us being an integrated company, an end-to-end company. So, going forward, $1 billion and $2 billion numbers, etc., will become more of a reality.Q: $1 billion by 2028, that's on, right?A: That's on.Q: A lot of sell-side analysts, all of last evening, were saying that maybe Kaynes Technologies had given some kind of hint that Q3 is going to be sort of a washout. But as you're telling us, Q4 is going to look much better, and you'll be ending at around ₹4,100 crore rather than the ₹4,400 crore that was expected earlier.A: We must look at two indicators. One indicator is what is known as a leading indicator, which is the order book. The second indicator is the trailing indicator, which is the actual performance on the street and so on. But, we weathered all of that, and we are still to deliver ₹4,100 crore without the support of any of the new businesses, which we most probably will do from the first quarter.For the full interview, watch the accompanying videoCatch all the latest updates from the stock market here

headline: Alembic Pharma secures USFDA final nod for Parkinson’s therapy tablets
condensed_text: Alembic Pharmaceuticals Limited on Friday, February 6, said it has received final approval from the US Food and Drug Administration  for its Abbreviated New Drug Application  for Carbidopa, Levodopa and Entacapone tablets, strengthening its presence in the US generics market.In a regulatory filing, the company said the approval covers multiple strengths of the combination therapy, including 12.5 mg/50 mg/200 mg, 18.75 mg/75 mg/200 mg, 25 mg/100 mg/200 mg, 31.25 mg/125 mg/200 mg, 37.5 mg/150 mg/200 mg and 50 mg/200 mg/200 mg. The product is therapeutically equivalent to Stalevo tablets of Orion Corporation, the reference listed drug.Carbidopa, levodopa and entacapone tablets are indicated for the treatment of Parkinson’s disease, the company said, adding that usage is subject to the approved label.With this approval, Alembic’s cumulative ANDA approvals from the USFDA now stand at 234, comprising 214 final approvals and 20 tentative approvals.For the December quarter, the company reported a 10.8% year-on-year rise in revenue to ₹1,876.3 crore. EBITDA grew 12.8% to ₹293.5 crore, while margins improved marginally to 15.6% from 15.4% a year ago. Net profit declined 4.1% YoY to ₹132 crore, impacted by a one-time expense of ₹42 crore linked to employee benefits following changes under the new labour code.Shares of Alembic Pharma were trading 2.45% down at ₹790.60 as of 12.08 pm on Friday. The stock has declined 16.63% in the past six months.Also Read: ITC shares see biggest single-day gain in 18 months after worst January on record

headline: Suzlon Energy shares: Motilal Oswal sees 55% upside; ICICI flags execution bottlenecks
condensed_text: Suzlon Energy’s consolidated revenue was below estimates as deliveries reached 617MW, 8 per cent lower than forecast, with Ebitda and adjusted net profit also coming lower than expectations, said Motilal Oswal Financial Services Ltd. For the three months ended on December 31, 2025, Suzlon Energy clocked a 14.8 per cent year-on-year (YoY) jump in the net profit at Rs 445.2 crore, while its revenue increased 42.4 per cent YoY to Rs 4,228.1 crore. The company's ebitda increased 48 per cent YoY to Rs 730.5 crore, while ebitda margins improved 70 basis points YoY to 17.3 per cent for the reported period. With strong order book and 4.5GW operational capacity, it has also been able to ramp up execution, delivering 1.6GW worth of wind turbines in 9 months, said ICICI Securities. Motilal Oswal’s valuation applies a target P/E of 30 times to FY28 estimated EPS, setting a price target of Rs 74 (suggest 55 per cent upside), slightly above the historical average two-year forward P/E of 27 times.
full_content:
Suzlon Energy target price : Domestic brokerage firms continue to remain largely positive on Suzlon Energy Ltd with select analysts expecting the stock to rise more than 55 per cent from its current levels. Other analysts, however, see some execution bottlenecks, resulting in trimmed target prices. Suzlon Energy’s consolidated revenue was below estimates as deliveries reached 617MW, 8 per cent lower than forecast, with Ebitda and adjusted net profit also coming lower than expectations, said Motilal Oswal Financial Services Ltd. Despite this, Motilal Oswal pointed to strong YoY Ebitda and delivery run rates for the first nine months, maintaining its earnings estimates. According to Motilal Oswal, key positives included management’s confidence in achieving FY26 guidance of 60 per cent growth across key indicators. Suzlon is on track to deliver 2.5GW in FY26, with 1.6GW already executed in nine months, a 66 per cent YoY increase. The order book reached 6.4GW by January 2026, with the EPC segment’s share rising to 27 per cent. "Installation pace slowed, with 442MW installed in nine months due to right of way, land, and grid evacuation challenges," it said. Motilal Oswal expects a sharp pick-up in installations in the fourth quarter. The ebitda margin in the wind turbine business moderated to 13.7 per cent in Q3, compared to 15-16 per cent in earlier quarters. For the three months ended on December 31, 2025, Suzlon Energy clocked a 14.8 per cent year-on-year (YoY) jump in the net profit at Rs 445.2 crore, while its revenue increased 42.4 per cent YoY to Rs 4,228.1 crore. The company's ebitda increased 48 per cent YoY to Rs 730.5 crore, while ebitda margins improved 70 basis points YoY to 17.3 per cent for the reported period. Suzlon saw a strong growth in order inflow in the last two years, which led to its orderbook more than doubling to 6.4GW as of January 2026. In FY26 so far, its order inflows stood strong at 3GW aided by PSU and C&I orders. With strong order book and 4.5GW operational capacity, it has also been able to ramp up execution, delivering 1.6GW worth of wind turbines in 9 months, said ICICI Securities. In Q3, its volume stood at 617MW which led to revenue/EBITDA/PAT growth of 42 per cent/48 per cent/15 per cent YoY. Management had guided for 2.5GW of volume for FY26 and it has reiterated that guidance, implying strong volume in Q4, it said. Shares of Suzlon Energy rebounded nearly 2 per cent from days low at Rs 47.28 to Rs 48.19 on Friday. The stock is still down from its 52-week high at Rs 74.30, hit nine months ago. Suzlon Energy shares hit a 52-week low of Rs 44.84 on January 27, 2026 and it is down 10 per cent in the last one month. Motilal Oswal’s valuation applies a target P/E of 30 times to FY28 estimated EPS, setting a price target of Rs 74 (suggest 55 per cent upside), slightly above the historical average two-year forward P/E of 27 times. MOFSL cited a government task force to address land and connectivity bottlenecks, which could support Suzlon’s growth in domestic and international markets. "We expect the order outlook for wind turbines to remain healthy for the next 2–3 years. Suzlon acknowledged wind project execution delays limiting its own execution potential and is targeting a higher share of EPC in its order book to get better control over project execution. It is also evaluating export opportunities," it added with a 'buy' and a target price of Rs 65 (Rs 76 earlier).

headline: Kalyan Jewellers Q3 results 2026 LIVE: What to expect from the jewellery stock?

full_content:

headline: Why Tata Motors’ India PV business may not offset JLR’s cyber drag: Jefferies explains
condensed_text: International brokerage Jefferies has highlighted mounting pressures at Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) after Tata Motors Passenger Vehicles (TMPV) reported a weak December quarter, with EBITDA plunging 91% YoY to about Rs 940 crore, though the performance was better than the brokerage’s estimates. While Q4 is expected to be better as production is likely to normalise in the March quarter as the cyberattack impact fades, Jefferies believes JLR continues to face several structural challenges that could weigh on profitability and growth. Jefferies noted that JLR’s break-even level has risen, with the business delivering an average EBITDA margin of just 3.6% in 9MFY26 on average quarterly volumes of 71,000 units, compared with over 9.6% margins in Q2 and Q3 FY22 at around 67,000 units per quarter. Jefferies expects Tata’s PV volumes to rise 18% YoY in FY26 and grow at an 11% CAGR over FY26 to FY28, with EBITDA margins improving toward 7.5 to 8.0% by FY27 to FY28. It expects FY27 and FY28 to be better than FY26 but estimates FY28 EPS to remain 26% below FY25 levels, with FY27 and FY28 EPS still 23 to 33% below Street expectations.
full_content: International brokerage Jefferies has highlighted mounting pressures at Jaguar Land Rover (JLR) after Tata Motors Passenger Vehicles (TMPV) reported a weak December quarter, with EBITDA plunging 91% YoY to about Rs 940 crore, though the performance was better than the brokerage’s estimates. Jefferies retained its Underperform rating on the stock with a target price of Rs 310, noting that improved India PV prospects are unlikely to fully offset the drag from JLR. The brokerage fine-tuned its FY27 and FY28 estimates, raising forecasts for India PV while cutting projections for JLR. While Q4 is expected to be better as production is likely to normalise in the March quarter as the cyberattack impact fades, Jefferies believes JLR continues to face several structural challenges that could weigh on profitability and growth. The cyberattack significantly disrupted operations in the second half of CY25, reducing production by roughly 50,000 units, or about 12% of FY25 volumes. Although volumes may recover in the near term, the brokerage sees persistent headwinds including rising competition, higher consumption tax in China, elevated customer acquisition and warranty costs, and the ongoing transition toward battery electric vehicles. In addition, key models such as Range Rover, Range Rover Sport, and Defender are now 3 to 5 years old. Jefferies noted that JLR’s break-even level has risen, with the business delivering an average EBITDA margin of just 3.6% in 9MFY26 on average quarterly volumes of 71,000 units, compared with over 9.6% margins in Q2 and Q3 FY22 at around 67,000 units per quarter. For FY26, JLR maintained its guidance of 0 to 2% EBIT margin and negative free cash flow of £2.2 billion to £2.5 billion. The company has deferred FY27 guidance to its June investor day, citing a business environment with more risks than opportunities. Live Events On the domestic front, Jefferies remains constructive on India’s passenger vehicle segment, supported by tailwinds such as a recent GST cut, improving liquidity conditions, and upcoming government wage hikes. The international brokerage, however, cautioned that it is unlikely to offset the JLR drag. Industry registration growth improved from 3% YoY during April to July to 15% YoY between August and January, and the brokerage expects an 8% industry CAGR over FY26 to FY28. Tata Motors’ passenger vehicle market share has recovered from 5% in FY16 to about 13 to 14% over FY23 to 9MFY26. The newly launched Sierra SUV has seen strong demand, with about 70,000 bookings on day one and a waiting period of 6 to 7 months, which should support growth. Jefferies expects Tata’s PV volumes to rise 18% YoY in FY26 and grow at an 11% CAGR over FY26 to FY28, with EBITDA margins improving toward 7.5 to 8.0% by FY27 to FY28. However, the brokerage remains cautious about the company achieving double-digit margins due to intense competition. It expects FY27 and FY28 to be better than FY26 but estimates FY28 EPS to remain 26% below FY25 levels, with FY27 and FY28 EPS still 23 to 33% below Street expectations. Tata Motors PV reported a consolidated loss of Rs 3,486 crore for the third quarter, compared with a profit of Rs 5,406 crore in the year-ago period. Revenue from operations declined 26% year-on-year (YoY) to Rs 70,108 crore. The company said both revenue and profit were significantly impacted by the cyber incident at Jaguar Land Rover (JLR), though it expects a strong recovery in the fourth quarter. TMPVL reported an EBIT loss of Rs 3,300 crore during the quarter. Domestic operations improved sequentially, supported by higher volumes and incentives. “Overall, it was a challenging quarter as anticipated on account of the carryover impact of Cyber Incident at JLR, while domestic business delivered robust revenue and margin improvement QoQ. We expect performance to significantly improve in Q4 with recovery at JLR and continuing growth in domestic market share,” said Dhiman Gupta, CFO, TMPVL. Tata Motors PV shares tumbled as much as 3.4% to their day’s low of Rs 361 per share on the BSE. (Disclaimer: Recommendations, suggestions, views and opinions given by the experts are their own. These do not represent the views of The Economic Times) Add as a Reliable and Trusted News Source Add Now! (You can now subscribe to our ETMarkets WhatsApp channel )

headline: AI impact on Indian IT to be worse than expected, says Bhavin Shah
condensed_text: The biggest risk for Indian IT stocks is that AI-led revenue deflation will be far worse than the 2–3% the market is currently factoring in — and that could force both earnings downgrades and valuation cuts, warns Bhavin Shah, Founder, CIO and CEO of Sameeksha Capital.Shah said the scale of productivity gains being reported across the industry has risen sharply in just a few months and will directly shrink the revenue pool for IT services companies. AI is surprising us with the magnitude of impact it is having latest… in areas that we had earlier probably not even anticipated.”Even if margins are protected, Shah warned, “if revenues are not growing or see erosion, that would obviously lead to an impact on EPS.”From an investor’s point of view, the bigger near-term risk is valuation. “When there is such a fast-moving technology having such a massive impact, many will prefer to stay on the sidelines and sort of wait it out — and that means there is definitely a risk for further multiple contraction,” Shah said.Also Read: Is it time to buy IT stocks yet? “By the time we finish a project, we might realise we could have done this differently based on the availability of some new AI tool.”Also Read: Devina Mehra on IT stocks: No reason to panic sell or bottom-fish right nowReflecting this caution, Shah said his firm is re-evaluating its IT holdings and confirmed that the direction is towards selling. He added that Sameeksha Capital had already sharply reduced its global technology exposure, warning that in the global AI race “there are several horses, all spending very aggressively — and chances are not all will be winners,” keeping both earnings and valuations under pressure.For the entire interview, watch the accompanying videoCatch all the latest updates from the stock market here
full_content: The biggest risk for Indian IT stocks is that AI-led revenue deflation will be far worse than the 2–3% the market is currently factoring in — and that could force both earnings downgrades and valuation cuts, warns Bhavin Shah, Founder, CIO and CEO of Sameeksha Capital.Shah said the scale of productivity gains being reported across the industry has risen sharply in just a few months and will directly shrink the revenue pool for IT services companies. “If it’s only going to be 2-3%, one can probably start to ignore it. But I suspect it will be bigger than 2-3%,” he said.Explaining why, he added, “Code development is only one part of the software cycle. There are other aspects like programme design, documentation, testing and quality assurance. AI is surprising us with the magnitude of impact it is having latest… in areas that we had earlier probably not even anticipated.”Even if margins are protected, Shah warned, “if revenues are not growing or see erosion, that would obviously lead to an impact on EPS.”From an investor’s point of view, the bigger near-term risk is valuation. “When there is such a fast-moving technology having such a massive impact, many will prefer to stay on the sidelines and sort of wait it out — and that means there is definitely a risk for further multiple contraction,” Shah said.Also Read: Is it time to buy IT stocks yet? BOB Capital’s Girish Pai answersHe also cautioned that fast-changing AI tools could delay large client decisions. “By the time we finish a project, we might realise we could have done this differently based on the availability of some new AI tool.”Also Read: Devina Mehra on IT stocks: No reason to panic sell or bottom-fish right nowReflecting this caution, Shah said his firm is re-evaluating its IT holdings and confirmed that the direction is towards selling. He added that Sameeksha Capital had already sharply reduced its global technology exposure, warning that in the global AI race “there are several horses, all spending very aggressively — and chances are not all will be winners,” keeping both earnings and valuations under pressure.For the entire interview, watch the accompanying videoCatch all the latest updates from the stock market here

headline: ITC, Godfrey Phillips, other cigarette stocks jump up to 13% amid reports of price hike
condensed_text: Shares of cigarette makers, including ITC , Godfrey Phillips and VST Industries , surged up to 13% on Friday after reports indicated companies had raised prices following the recent tax hike, passing on higher costs to consumers. Under the new framework, excise duties on cigarettes were restructured to a range of Rs 2,050 to Rs 8,500 per 1,000 sticks, alongside a 40% GST. However, the Budget also clarified that the effective duty rate will continue at 25% through a notification, meaning there is no immediate increase in tax outgo for cigarette companies. In the December quarter, ITC reported 6.2% year-on-year revenue growth, driven by double-digit growth in FMCG-Others and steady momentum in cigarettes. Margins in the cigarette segment, however, slipped to a multi-quarter low of 59.9%, contracting 163 basis points YoY due to the consumption of high-cost leaf inventory.
full_content: Shares of cigarette makers, including ITC , Godfrey Phillips and VST Industries , surged up to 13% on Friday after reports indicated companies had raised prices following the recent tax hike, passing on higher costs to consumers. The rally was also supported by value buying at lower levels after a sharp correction triggered by the cigarette taxation overhaul announced on December 31, which came into effect from February. Godfrey Phillips shares rose as much as 13% to their day’s high of Rs 2,240 per share on the BSE. ITC, one of India’s largest FMCG majors, rose 6% to Rs 328 per share. VST Industries rose 6% to its day’s high of Rs 243 on the BSE. A report by CNBC TV-18 stated that higher-priced cigarette packets have been introduced in the market. Price hikes of between 15% to 30% have been taken across the board. For Godfrey Phillips, the 97mm pack is now priced at Rs 300 from Rs 240 earlier, a hike of 25%, according to the report. Under the new framework, excise duties on cigarettes were restructured to a range of Rs 2,050 to Rs 8,500 per 1,000 sticks, alongside a 40% GST. This has materially raised the overall tax burden on cigarettes, triggering concerns over demand, margins and the risk of increased illicit trade. Adding to the unease is a technical change in the National Calamity Contingent Duty (NCCD) announced in the Budget. Live Events The government raised the statutory NCCD rate on tobacco products from 25% to 60%, with effect from May 1, 2026. However, the Budget also clarified that the effective duty rate will continue at 25% through a notification, meaning there is no immediate increase in tax outgo for cigarette companies. In simple terms, this is not a tax hike today, but a future enabling provision. The government has created room to raise the duty later without changing the law again. In the December quarter, ITC reported 6.2% year-on-year revenue growth, driven by double-digit growth in FMCG-Others and steady momentum in cigarettes. Cigarette revenues grew 8%, supported by 7% volume growth. Margins in the cigarette segment, however, slipped to a multi-quarter low of 59.9%, contracting 163 basis points YoY due to the consumption of high-cost leaf inventory. Management has indicated that leaf procurement prices have moderated in the current crop cycle, which could support margins in the coming quarters. Axis Securities has said ITC's long-term growth trajectory remains intact, even though cigarette volumes could face pressure in the medium term due to higher taxes. It also highlighted continued progress in non-cigarette businesses such as FMCG, hotels and agri-business. headline: Astral sees stronger Q4 outlook as demand improves and margins set to rise
condensed_text: Ahmedabad-based manufacturer of building materials Astral Limited remains optimistic about the fourth quarter, traditionally the strongest period for the building materials industry, driven by seasonal demand and operating leverage benefits.With Astral holding low-cost inventory and benefiting from recent price increases, margins are expected to improve sequentially.Strong restocking activity and a visible uptick in demand since December have further strengthened confidence of surpassing third-quarter volume levels, even in a rising price environment.Hiranand Savlani, Executive Director and Chief Financial Officer of Astral Limited, said the company is likely to come close to achieving double-digit topline growth for the full year, even though revenue growth stands at around 8% for the first nine months.Beyond plumbing, Astral continues to invest in scaling up its adhesives, paints, and bathware businesses, which are steadily gaining traction despite being at a relatively early stage.While margins in these segments may remain modest in the near term due to expansion-led costs, the company expects strong topline growth and improved profitability over the medium term as scale benefits kick in.In October-December quarter , Astral reported revenue of ₹1,542 crore, net profit of ₹108 crore, and margin of 15.39%. What is the situation that you are seeing on the ground currently and do you believe that, based on what you have witnessed so far does that improve in the fourth quarter, going into the final quarter of the year?A: If you see industry dynamics, the industry is not growing that high because Astral did a lot of decentralisation in the recent time and because of that, our volumes were excellent. We are expecting the volume will further inch up, because the industry was passing through a very tough time.Last three years, if you see the polymer prices were going down, and this is the first quarter where we are seeing that, at least now the bottom out is being taken place, and from here on, the prices have started going up. We are expecting better volume than what was there in Q3.Q: Do you think you will exceed your volume growth despite higher prices, and if you could break your Q4 targets, volume and value-wise?A: Normally, whenever the price rise is there, a lot of restocking take place in the street. Since you mentioned you are on fairly decent, low priced inventory right now, when do you expect the realisations to recover?A: Q4 onward you will see the realisation will start picking up.Q: From a medium- to long-term standpoint, what kind of revenue mix are you expecting coming in from the PVC plumbing business?
full_content: Ahmedabad-based manufacturer of building materials Astral Limited remains optimistic about the fourth quarter, traditionally the strongest period for the building materials industry, driven by seasonal demand and operating leverage benefits.With Astral holding low-cost inventory and benefiting from recent price increases, margins are expected to improve sequentially.Strong restocking activity and a visible uptick in demand since December have further strengthened confidence of surpassing third-quarter volume levels, even in a rising price environment.Hiranand Savlani, Executive Director and Chief Financial Officer of Astral Limited, said the company is likely to come close to achieving double-digit topline growth for the full year, even though revenue growth stands at around 8% for the first nine months.Beyond plumbing, Astral continues to invest in scaling up its adhesives, paints, and bathware businesses, which are steadily gaining traction despite being at a relatively early stage.While margins in these segments may remain modest in the near term due to expansion-led costs, the company expects strong topline growth and improved profitability over the medium term as scale benefits kick in.In October-December quarter , Astral reported revenue of ₹1,542 crore, net profit of ₹108 crore, and margin of 15.39%. These are the edited excerpts of the interview.Q: Your volumes were 16.8% fairly good and within the range as well that the street was projecting. What is the situation that you are seeing on the ground currently and do you believe that, based on what you have witnessed so far does that improve in the fourth quarter, going into the final quarter of the year?A: If you see industry dynamics, the industry is not growing that high because Astral did a lot of decentralisation in the recent time and because of that, our volumes were excellent. We are expecting the volume will further inch up, because the industry was passing through a very tough time.Last three years, if you see the polymer prices were going down, and this is the first quarter where we are seeing that, at least now the bottom out is being taken place, and from here on, the prices have started going up. That will help us in the further growth into the volume. We are expecting better volume than what was there in Q3.Q: Do you think you will exceed your volume growth despite higher prices, and if you could break your Q4 targets, volume and value-wise?A: Normally, whenever the price rise is there, a lot of restocking take place in the street. And secondly, there is a genuine uptick in the demand, which we are seeing from December onward. December was excellent number. January was good. February started on a very good note.So, because of that, it looks clearly that even if the higher price also, we will be able to surpass the volume what we have done in Q3.Q: I am sure you must be sitting on some low-price inventory as well. What kind of margins can you target in Q4 because of that? And going forward for FY27, what's your volume and value growth guidance, along with margins? A: Definitely we are sitting with a sizeable, low inventory cost. So, that is going to benefit us in Q4, as a result, margin should be a better in Q4. Historically, if you see, Q4 in our industry is the peak, we are generating the maximum volume. So, economy of scale advantage will always be there in Q4 and now with this price rise, it is double advantage to us.Definitely, Q4 will be much better. Once we will close this year, based on that, we will give our guidance.Q: What about top line, you had mentioned double digits for this year. You are at 8% right now for the first nine months. Do you cross them? A: It looks like that, we will be closer to that.Q: What about your adhesives and paints business? Paint industry, the biggies, have reported their numbers, and it's not particularly good, impacted by extended monsoons and, a shorter festive window as well. But you have managed to grow over 20%, what led to that? What's your plan here -- are you making margins, profit, have you broken even here?A: Right now, we are in a growth phase; we are opening in the whole new state, and from there, we are trying to catch the volume. In this quarter, we have grown by 21%. So going forward, we are targeting that may be one more year EBITDA may not be that lucrative, may be a lower-single digit kind of level next year.But the topline growth will be very high, as we are at a very nascent stage of the business and our base is low. So, on that low base growing higher percentage will not be a big challenge and then economy of scale will start playing. That will help us to generate the EBITDA positively.Q: Does the same apply to realisations as well? Since you mentioned you are on fairly decent, low priced inventory right now, when do you expect the realisations to recover?A: Q4 onward you will see the realisation will start picking up.Q: From a medium- to long-term standpoint, what kind of revenue mix are you expecting coming in from the PVC plumbing business? How much of that comes in from paints, adhesives and even your bathware division, which has done well just about broken even. What's the contribution target from these places? A: From here on, we are expecting that other businesses will keep generating between 33-35% kind of ratio and the plumbing will generate 67-68% kind of contribution. Bathware is doing very well. You can see in the last quarter's number also; we have grown by 36% which is a very encouraging number for us. The way we are seeing is that the acceptance is increasing in the project level going forward. We are going to even grow in much better way, as initial journey is always tough because it's the trial in the market.One day, will test our product. Then, we can start getting the bigger ticket size. Initially, they will give me one or two towers, but afterward once they test our product they can definitely give us the full projects also. Hence, revenue jump will be very high maybe one year down the length from here, but right now, still at this growth, we are at a testing level.Follow our live blog for more stock market updatesFollow our live blog for more updates on Q3 results

headline: Greaves Cotton Q3 Results: Profit jumps 23% YoY as margin expands
condensed_text: Greaves Cotton Q3 Results: Profit jumps 23% YoY as margin expands. Greaves Cotton Ltd posted healthy set of numbers for the December quarter  on January 6, reporting a 22.6% year-on-year increase in net profit at ₹25.5 crore, compared with ₹20.8 crore in the year ago period.Revenue for the quarter rose 16.6% YoY to ₹875.5 crore from ₹750.6 crore in Q3 FY25, reflecting steady growth across its business segments. Operating performance strengthened materially, with EBITDA surging 56.3% YoY to ₹61.8 crore, up from ₹39.5 crore a year earlier.Improved operating leverage and cost efficiencies drove a notable expansion in margins, which stood at 7% in Q3 FY26 compared with 5.3% in the corresponding quarter last year.Following the earnings announcement, shares of Greaves Cotton were trading at ₹172.18 on the NSE, up 1.64% on the day, after touching an intraday high of ₹177.50.Also Read: Kaynes Tech Q3 Results: Shares fall 6% after earnings miss across the board, guidance cutGreaves Cotton is a diversified engineering company with a presence across clean mobility, power, farm equipment, aftermarket solutions and retail electric mobility through its EV-focused businesses.

headline: Shah Rukh Khan to reunite with Farah Khan after 12 years for Main Hoon Na 2? What we know
condensed_text: Shah Rukh Khan and filmmaker Farah Khan will reportedly reunite after almost 12 years for Main Hoon Na 2, a sequel to their 2004 blockbuster. Shah Rukh is currently working on his next theatrical release, King.It was reported last year that the filmmaker was working on a script, and the project now appears to be a priority for the duo.According to a report by Pinkvilla, the actor-director duo is reportedly in discussions for a reunion for Main Hoon Na 2, a frontrunner for the superstar's upcoming release, King. The idea is said to elevate the emotion and entertainment quotient of the sequel, while SRK will explore two contrasting characters," sources told the outlet.Also Read: Makers of Ghooskhor Pandat pull promotional materials, Director Neeraj Pandey says, 'We understand the hurt’For the sequel, the makers plan to reunite the original ensemble with new stars, and it will be a patriotic film like the first instalment. It has been confirmed by sources that the core story idea was personally conceived by Shah Rukh Khan and has since been transitioned into a full screenplay by writer Aakash Kaushik.While the project is in active development, a final decision is expected after SRK hears a full narration around May 2026, after wrapping up King. He will take a call on the project post the narration, while the writing process continues in full swing," it added.Main Hoon Naa, the debut directorial of Farah Khan, hit the cinemas in 2004.
full_content: Shah Rukh Khan and filmmaker Farah Khan will reportedly reunite after almost 12 years for Main Hoon Na 2, a sequel to their 2004 blockbuster. An official announcement is pending. Shah Rukh is currently working on his next theatrical release, King.It was reported last year that the filmmaker was working on a script, and the project now appears to be a priority for the duo.According to a report by Pinkvilla, the actor-director duo is reportedly in discussions for a reunion for Main Hoon Na 2, a frontrunner for the superstar's upcoming release, King. This potential collaboration will be their first film together after a long gap and could feature the actor in a double role."Farah Khan has cracked an exciting double-role concept for Shah Rukh Khan, which has excited the superstar. The idea is said to elevate the emotion and entertainment quotient of the sequel, while SRK will explore two contrasting characters," sources told the outlet.Also Read: Makers of Ghooskhor Pandat pull promotional materials, Director Neeraj Pandey says, 'We understand the hurt’For the sequel, the makers plan to reunite the original ensemble with new stars, and it will be a patriotic film like the first instalment. It has been confirmed by sources that the core story idea was personally conceived by Shah Rukh Khan and has since been transitioned into a full screenplay by writer Aakash Kaushik.While the project is in active development, a final decision is expected after SRK hears a full narration around May 2026, after wrapping up King."Shah Rukh Khan is expected to hear the complete narration of Main Hoon Na 2 after wrapping up the shoot of King around May 2026. He will take a call on the project post the narration, while the writing process continues in full swing," it added.Main Hoon Naa, the debut directorial of Farah Khan, hit the cinemas in 2004. The film was a hit at the box office.Also Read: Badshah to represent India in NBA all-star celebrity game in LA

headline: Data Patterns shares rise 9% on Q3 earnings, record high order book; check details
condensed_text:
Sentiment was also positive after the defence firm reported its highest ever order book at Rs 1,868 crore (Rs 760 crore orders confirmed plus Rs 1107.8 crore negotiated/awaited) as of Q3 FY26. Revenue in Q3 rose 39% to Rs 179 crore in the quarter ended December 31, 2025 compared to Rs 128 crore in the quarter ended December 31, 2024. S. Rangarajan, Chairman & Managing Director, Data Patterns (India) said, “We are encouraged by the strong performance in Q3 and 9MFY26, driven by robust execution and sustained demand across key programs and segments. With a strong executable pipeline, we remain confident of achieving our full-year guidance.”
For the nine months ended December 2025, the revenue rose 73% to Rs 602.22 crore from Rs 347.86 crore for the nine months ended December 31, 2024. Net profit rose 23% to Rs 132.99 crore for the nine months ended December 31, 2025 from Rs 107.73 crore in the nine months ended December 31, 2024.
full_content:
Shares of Data Patterns India (Ltd) gained 9% in the afternoon session on Friday after the defence firm reported its Q3 earnings. Data Patterns shares rose 9.19% to Rs 2758.90 in the current session against the previous close of Rs 2526.55 on BSE.
Sentiment was also positive after the defence firm reported its highest ever order book at Rs 1,868 crore (Rs 760 crore orders confirmed plus Rs 1107.8 crore negotiated/awaited) as of Q3 FY26. The defence major also provided strong revenue visibility for the next two to three years (around 2.6x FY25 sales).
Net profit rose 31% to Rs 58 crore in Q3 from Rs 45 crore in the quarter ended December 31, 2024. Revenue in Q3 rose 39% to Rs 179 crore in the quarter ended December 31, 2025 compared to Rs 128 crore in the quarter ended December 31, 2024. EBITDA in Q3 increased 44% to Rs 78 crore in Q3 FY 2025-26 from Rs 54 crore in Q3 FY 2024-25. EBITDA margin came at 45% for the quarter ended December 31, 2025.
The company said it remains committed to a revenue growth rate of 20-25% and EBITDA margins of around 35-40% in FY26.
S. Rangarajan, Chairman & Managing Director, Data Patterns (India) said, “We are encouraged by the strong performance in Q3 and 9MFY26, driven by robust execution and sustained demand across key programs and segments. Healthy growth in revenues and profitability reflects the strength of our operating model. Order inflows during FY26 have been encouraging, reinforcing our growth outlook. With a strong executable pipeline, we remain confident of achieving our full-year guidance.”
For the nine months ended December 2025, the revenue rose 73% to Rs 602.22 crore from Rs 347.86 crore for the nine months ended December 31, 2024.
Net profit rose 23% to Rs 132.99 crore for the nine months ended December 31, 2025 from Rs 107.73 crore in the nine months ended December 31, 2024.
PAT margin came at 23% for the nine months.
Revenue from operations increased by 86% to Rs 579.92 crore in the nine months to December 2025 from Rs 312.14 crore a year ago.
Operational EBIDTA rose 42% to Rs 178.14 crore in the corresponding nine months ended December 31, 2025 from Rs 125.51 crore a year ago. EBITDA margin stood at 31% during the period.
Data Patterns (India) Limited is an India-based vertically integrated defence and aerospace electronics solutions provider catering to the indigenously developed defense products industry. Its portfolio includes COTS Boards, ATE and Test systems, Space Systems, and Radio Frequency and Microwave. It designs COTS module products that are used in rugged applications and automatic test equipment platforms.

headline: Uno Minda targets firmer growth on expanding product pipeline, deeper engagement with OEMs: CFO
condensed_text: As Uno Minda sharpens its focus on technology-led products, premium feature adoption and electrification, the company remains confident of sustaining growth ahead of the broader auto industry, supported by a strong and expanding product pipeline and deeper engagement with original equipment manufacturer  customers across segments.That confidence is underpinned by a steady financial performance. In the October-December quarter of 2025 , year-on-year, Uno Minda reported revenue growth of 20% at ₹5,018 crore , earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation  up 21% at ₹554 crore  and an EBITDA margin of 11% .The Gurugram-based company has a market capitalisation of about ₹68,034.31 crore, and its shares have gained nearly 14% over the past year.Below are the edited excerpts from the interview with Sunil Bohra, Group Chief Financial Officer, Uno Minda Group.Q: India–US and India–EU, the free trade agreements , in what way does this change things for the Indian auto component sector, and what are the tangible benefits that you see?A: It definitely opens up a lot of opportunities for exports from India. Now that we have the clarity, things will speed up, and it will definitely open up a lot of opportunities for exports of auto and auto components.Also Read: Bajaj Auto sees export run-rate holding above 2 lakh units a monthQ: When we look at the auto sales numbers, it looks like the entry-level cars have done better, and that impacts the value proposition for you — yours is a premiumisation play. We are not going to give actual growth numbers because we do not normally talk about the OE one, but definitely our endeavour has consistently been, on an annual basis, whatever the industry grows, we consistently grow at least 1.5 times or more, and we are pretty confident that we should be able to deliver that.Q: How do you see the business evolving from here on? Some of the two-wheeler components will get into production next fiscal year.There are a lot of these products which will get into SOP at the end of 2026 and early 2027, so this consistently will help us improve our offering per vehicle, which will actually translate into the actual realisable.
full_content: As Uno Minda sharpens its focus on technology-led products, premium feature adoption and electrification, the company remains confident of sustaining growth ahead of the broader auto industry, supported by a strong and expanding product pipeline and deeper engagement with original equipment manufacturer  customers across segments.That confidence is underpinned by a steady financial performance. In the October-December quarter of 2025 , year-on-year, Uno Minda reported revenue growth of 20% at ₹5,018 crore , earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation  up 21% at ₹554 crore  and an EBITDA margin of 11% .The Gurugram-based company has a market capitalisation of about ₹68,034.31 crore, and its shares have gained nearly 14% over the past year.Below are the edited excerpts from the interview with Sunil Bohra, Group Chief Financial Officer, Uno Minda Group.Q: India–US and India–EU, the free trade agreements , in what way does this change things for the Indian auto component sector, and what are the tangible benefits that you see?A: It definitely opens up a lot of opportunities for exports from India. We have been seeing that a lot of the auto component players like us have been exporting to the EU and the US. And now, with this stability in terms of tariffs and clarity, and also tariffs going down, definitely, it will open up a lot of opportunities. For example, we have also been in discussions with some of our customers. But because of some of these situations, things have not been progressing as one would have expected. Now that we have the clarity, things will speed up, and it will definitely open up a lot of opportunities for exports of auto and auto components.Also Read: Bajaj Auto sees export run-rate holding above 2 lakh units a monthQ: When we look at the auto sales numbers, it looks like the entry-level cars have done better, and that impacts the value proposition for you — yours is a premiumisation play. What should we expect in terms of volume and value growth going forward?A: In terms of vehicles being sold and with the current goods and services tax , it was expected that it would trigger more entry-level two-wheelers and four-wheelers sales. And that's what the data has been suggesting, because their kit value, obviously, is lesser in an entry-level car versus a premium car or a premium bike.Having said that, there has been a change in terms of the adoption of a lot of these premium features. So as the cost goes down, as the volume increases, even these premium features — which, say, for example, used to be in entry-segment cars or 350cc bikes or 250cc bikes — have been coming down to D-segment and C-segment vehicles, etc. So, the adoption has been increasing. For example, airbags used to have very low penetration. Now, it has been consistently increasing. The same thing goes for alloy wheels and some of the lights.As we move forward, we do expect this premiumisation play even to get into some of these entry-level segments — maybe not in the base models, but definitely in terms of the upper models of those same segments. Moving forward, we do expect this momentum to continue.Also Read: US duty relief could trigger fresh orders for Indian industrial and auto suppliersWe have been significantly expanding in terms of our product profile and in building our capacities in line with our customers. We are pretty confident that this growth momentum will continue. We are not going to give actual growth numbers because we do not normally talk about the OE one, but definitely our endeavour has consistently been, on an annual basis, whatever the industry grows, we consistently grow at least 1.5 times or more, and we are pretty confident that we should be able to deliver that.Q: How do you see the business evolving from here on? If you tell us the content per vehicle that you're dealing with currently — both two-wheelers as well as four-wheelers — and how you see that number scale up? Give us a broader time horizon, say, in the next 12 months, as well as 24 months. How do you see this improving, because you have been hinting about this in the past?A: There are some products which are currently in the development phase and which will get into the production phase sometime in the next calendar year. For example, sunroofs will get into production next year. Some of the EV-play components for four-wheelers will get into production next year. Some of the two-wheeler components will get into production next fiscal year.There are a lot of these products which will get into SOP at the end of 2026 and early 2027, so this consistently will help us improve our offering per vehicle, which will actually translate into the actual realisable. On top of it, some of the existing products are also seeing some switches getting into habit-based switches, or horns getting into electromechanical horns. Electrification for lamps has been a consistent journey for the last few years, and we have been seeing that sensor adoption is increasing. So, we are very optimistic.Watch the interview in the accompanying videoCatch all the latest updates from the stock market here

headline: Paisalo Digital Q3 Results: Net profit remains flat at₹66 crore
condensed_text: Paisalo Digital , a constituent of the BSE Smallcap index, announced its December quarter results on Thursday, reporting a consolidated profit after tax (PAT) of ₹ 66.3 crore for the quarter ended December 31, 2025, compared with ₹ 62.4 crore in the year-ago period. Total income for the December quarter stood at ₹ 240.1 crore, up from ₹ 203.8 crore in the corresponding quarter last year and ₹ 224.0 crore in Q2 FY26. In late January, the company had announced that it had redeemed ₹ 1 crore of unlisted, unsecured, redeemable, non-convertible debentures (NCDs) by exercising an early call option. Earlier this year, Paisalo Digital raised ₹ 188.5 crore as part of its efforts to optimise funding costs, improve capital efficiency, and support business expansion. In an exchange filing dated January 6, the company said it had “successfully raised nearly ₹ 188.5 crore at an annual ROI of 8.5% through its latest listed issuances in Q3,” adding that the fundraise underscored its strong credit profile, prudent risk-management practices, and solid balance-sheet position.
full_content:
Paisalo Digital , a constituent of the BSE Smallcap index, announced its December quarter results on Thursday, reporting a consolidated profit after tax (PAT) of ₹ 66.3 crore for the quarter ended December 31, 2025, compared with ₹ 62.4 crore in the year-ago period. However, on a sequential basis, the net profit showed improvement by 30% as it stood at ₹ 51 crore in the September quarter (Q2FY26).
Total income for the December quarter stood at ₹ 240.1 crore, up from ₹ 203.8 crore in the corresponding quarter last year and ₹ 224.0 crore in Q2 FY26. The company posted a net income of ₹ 243 crore as compared to ₹ 181 crore in the year ago quarter.
The net interest income stood at ₹ 148 crore as compared to ₹ 99 crore in December 2024 quarter, as per the company's earnings' filing.
Meanwhile, the company has recently been in the spotlight. In late January, the company had announced that it had redeemed ₹ 1 crore of unlisted, unsecured, redeemable, non-convertible debentures (NCDs) by exercising an early call option. According to the company, the move will help reduce long-term debt well ahead of the instruments scheduled maturity.
Earlier this year, Paisalo Digital raised ₹ 188.5 crore as part of its efforts to optimise funding costs, improve capital efficiency, and support business expansion. The small-cap NBFC mobilised the funds during the third quarter through its latest listed issuances, securing an annual return on investment of 8.5%.
In an exchange filing dated January 6, the company said it had “successfully raised nearly ₹ 188.5 crore at an annual ROI of 8.5% through its latest listed issuances in Q3,” adding that the fundraise underscored its strong credit profile, prudent risk-management practices, and solid balance-sheet position.
Paisalo Digital also noted that the capital infusion is expected to lower its overall cost of funds, strengthen its medium-term capital base, and expand its lending capacity.

full_content: Multimodal logistics firm Gateway Distriparks Ltd on Friday  reported its Q3 results with net profit declining 85% year-on-year to ₹68 crore from ₹455.4 crore.Revenue grew 39.2% year-on-year to ₹560.4 crore compared with ₹402.5 crore in the same quarter last year. EBITDA increased 26.6% year-on-year to ₹122.4 crore from ₹96.7 crore. EBITDA margin stood at 21.8% versus 24% in the year-ago period.The company announced a second interim dividend for FY26 of ₹0.75 per share, along with a special interim dividend of ₹1.25 per share. The special interim dividend is a one-time, non-recurring payout, declared in recognition of the company achieving a net debt-free position for the first time since inception and marking 30 years since the acquisition of land for its first facility, the Nhava Sheva CFS.Also Read: Gateway Distriparks to build ₹150 crore Indore cargo terminal for 1.2 lakh containersProfit before tax was reported at ₹-3.20 crore, with year-to-date PBT at ₹-3.48 crore. These figures were impacted due to the consolidation of accounts after Snowman Logistics transitioned from an associate company to a subsidiary effective December 24, 2024.An exceptional income of ₹390.77 crore arising from fair valuation of equity and assets on consolidation of Snowman Logistics Ltd, which became a subsidiary from December 24, 2024, was included in PBT and PAT of Q3 and year-to-date FY25. This exceptional income has been removed from the reported figures above to ensure comparability of numbers.Prem Kishan Dass Gupta, Chairman & Managing Director, said, "Normally, Q3 is a weaker quarter, but our numbers continued to remain strong in line with the last few quarters. We are very optimistic about the future with the announcement of the Free Trade Agreement signed with the EU, along with the trade deal made with the USA. When all these agreements get ratified, it will lead to a big boost in global trade for India.Also Read: Gateway Distriparks aims to quadruple domestic cargo volumes in 2 years via Ankleshwar dealAdditionally, we started our domestic rail services from MMLP New Ankleshwar in October 2025 and are seeing continued traction. With the above developments, we are expanding our rail capacity by purchasing 3 new high-capacity rakes as well as swapping 3 of our older rakes on lease for 3 higher-capacity rakes. With this, by the end of Q1 next year, we will have 37 rakes."Shares of Gateway Distriparks Ltd ended at ₹61.18, up by ₹1.06, or 1.76%, on the BSE.

headline: Adani Power re-positions its fleet of thermal plants as grid balancers; targets 24 GW capacity addition
condensed_text:
FILE PHOTO: A view shows high-tension electricity power line pylon outside Adani Power's thermal power generation plant at Mundra in the western state of Gujarat, India
AMIT DAVE
As India’s power grid tilts rapidly towards renewables, Adani Power is repositioning its thermal fleet as a support system for grid stability, with plants increasingly acting as balancing power sources to enable larger renewable integration, even as the company rolls out a 24-GW capacity expansion plan through FY32 backed by long-term power purchase agreements. The (thermal) power plants will now act more as balancing power plants and therefore the focus will be on keeping the plant uptime as high as possible, rather than actually trying to maximise the PLF,” said Dilip Jha, Chief Financial Officer of Adani Power. The power plants that we are setting up… will use a lesser amount of coal to generate higher amounts of power — up to 5–10 percent of advantage when compared to older technology,” he recently told investors adding that most projects are located close to coal sources, helping lower logistics costs. Mahan Phase-2 is around 80 per cent complete, Raipur Phase-2 about 44 per cent, Raigarh Phase-2 close to 38 pe rcent, while construction at Korba Phase-2 has resumed, the company said. In FY28, another 2.4 GW, FY29 another 2.4 GW, FY30 about 8 GW, FY31 around 5.6 GW and another 2.4 GW thereafter,” Jha said, adding that the revived Korba Phase-2 project will see its first unit commissioned by mid-next year and the second by year-end.
full_content:
FILE PHOTO: A view shows high-tension electricity power line pylon outside Adani Power's thermal power generation plant at Mundra in the western state of Gujarat, India
AMIT DAVE
As India’s power grid tilts rapidly towards renewables, Adani Power is repositioning its thermal fleet as a support system for grid stability, with plants increasingly acting as balancing power sources to enable larger renewable integration, even as the company rolls out a 24-GW capacity expansion plan through FY32 backed by long-term power purchase agreements.
“Now the entire game has become to keep generation capacity available to help integrate more renewable power into the grid and to continue to supply base load power. The (thermal) power plants will now act more as balancing power plants and therefore the focus will be on keeping the plant uptime as high as possible, rather than actually trying to maximise the PLF,” said Dilip Jha, Chief Financial Officer of Adani Power.
Jha said the upcoming capacities will be built using advanced technology to improve efficiency and reduce fuel consumption.
The power plants that we are setting up… will use a lesser amount of coal to generate higher amounts of power — up to 5–10 percent of advantage when compared to older technology,” he recently told investors adding that most projects are located close to coal sources, helping lower logistics costs.
The company currently operates 18.5 GW of capacity, of which around 90 percent is tied up under long- and medium-term power purchase agreements (PPAs) with state distribution companies (DISCOMs).
“For the new capacities that we are planning to set up we intend to tie up for long term PPAs, so going forward we are reducing our merchant exposure,” Jha said.
Adani Power is executing a 23.7-GW thermal expansion programme, with multiple brownfield projects progressing across central and eastern India. Mahan Phase-2 is around 80 per cent complete, Raipur Phase-2 about 44 per cent, Raigarh Phase-2 close to 38 pe rcent, while construction at Korba Phase-2 has resumed, the company said.
These projects are scheduled to be commissioned in phases starting FY27. “Broadly speaking, around 2.9 GW will be commissioned next year. In FY28, another 2.4 GW, FY29 another 2.4 GW, FY30 about 8 GW, FY31 around 5.6 GW and another 2.4 GW thereafter,” Jha said, adding that the revived Korba Phase-2 project will see its first unit commissioned by mid-next year and the second by year-end.
On demand trends, Jha said higher hydro generation and renewable output during the extended monsoon temporarily reduced thermal power’s share in the energy mix during Q3FY26.
Thermal contribution fell to 73 percent from 76 percent earlier, while renewables and large hydro increased to 24 percent from around 20 per cent.
“This is transient,” he said, adding that rising household consumption and industrial activity are expected to drive long-term demand.
India’s peak power requirement could rise to 380–400 GW by FY32, which would continue to support demand for thermal power even as renewable capacity expands.
Published on  February 6, 2026
BACK TO TOP

headline: Telcos owe govt ₹1.77 lakh cr in AGR dues till FY25; Voda Idea liability at ₹89,952 cr
condensed_text: Telcos owe govt ₹1.77 lakh cr in AGR dues till FY25; Voda Idea liability at ₹89,952 cr. Telecom operators' total adjusted gross revenue dues up to the financial year 2024-25 payable to the government stood at over ₹1.77 lakh crore, according to official data shared with Parliament. The data show that the total liability on debt-ridden Vodafone Idea (Vi) stands at ₹89,952 crore, Bharti Group ₹51,091 crore, Tata Group ₹20,426 crore, MTNL ₹14,462 crore and Reliance Jio Infocomm ₹1,984 crore. In the case of Vodafone Idea Limited (VIL), the AGR dues pertaining to the period from FY2006–07 to FY 2018–19 have been frozen at ₹87,695 crore. "The Committee comprises a retired Secretary-level officer of the Government of India and a representative of the Comptroller and Auditor General of India (CAG), as nominated by the CAG.
full_content:
Telecom operators' total adjusted gross revenue dues up to the financial year 2024-25 payable to the government stood at over ₹1.77 lakh crore, according to official data shared with Parliament.
The data show that the total liability on debt-ridden Vodafone Idea (Vi) stands at ₹89,952 crore, Bharti Group ₹51,091 crore, Tata Group ₹20,426 crore, MTNL ₹14,462 crore and Reliance Jio Infocomm ₹1,984 crore.
In the case of Vodafone Idea Limited (VIL), the AGR dues pertaining to the period from FY2006–07 to FY 2018–19 have been frozen at ₹87,695 crore.
The frozen dues are also subject to reassessment.
Parliament has been informed that the Department of Telecom formed a committee on January 30 to decide on the outcome of the reassessment of frozen dues of Vi.
"The Committee comprises a retired Secretary-level officer of the Government of India and a representative of the Comptroller and Auditor General of India (CAG), as nominated by the CAG.
"The Committee shall finalise the outcome of the reassessment within a period of two months, unless extended. The decision of the committee shall be final, binding on both parties (DoT and VIL)," the official statement shared with Parliament said.
Published on  February 6, 2026
BACK TO TOP

headline: Mahindra & Mahindra to invest ₹15,000 crore to build vehicle manufacturing plant in Nagpur
condensed_text:
The decade-long investment plan includes acquiring over 2,000 acres across three locations, including a 150-acre supplier park in Sambhajinagar and land in the Igatpuri-Nashik region. (A file photo)
WALDO SWIEGERS
Mahindra & Mahindra said on Friday it will invest ₹15,000 crore to set up manufacturing facility in Nagpur , Maharashtra with the capacity to produce 5 lakh vehicles and 1 lakh tractors annually. The company said the facility, its largest in the country, will be developed over an area of 1,500 acres in Vidarbha with a 150-acre supplier park in Sambhajinagar. It will also acquire land in the Igatpuri-Nashik region to expand current product and engine capacities, as well as to support the growth of its Advanced Technology business. The automotive facility will support Mahindra Auto’s next-generation platforms, including the NU_IQ architecture, and will be capable of manufacturing vehicles across multiple powertrains including internal combustion engine, electric vehicles and future technologies—for both domestic and global markets.
full_content:
The decade-long investment plan includes acquiring over 2,000 acres across three locations, including a 150-acre supplier park in Sambhajinagar and land in the Igatpuri-Nashik region. The facility will support next-generation platforms and multiple powertrains, including EVs. (A file photo)
WALDO SWIEGERS
Mahindra & Mahindra said on Friday it will invest ₹15,000 crore to set up manufacturing facility in Nagpur , Maharashtra with the capacity to produce 5 lakh vehicles and 1 lakh tractors annually.
The company said the facility, its largest in the country, will be developed over an area of 1,500 acres in Vidarbha with a 150-acre supplier park in Sambhajinagar.
It will also acquire land in the Igatpuri-Nashik region to expand current product and engine capacities, as well as to support the growth of its Advanced Technology business.
The planned investment is over a period of 10 years the company will acquire over 2000 acres across three locations to further strengthen its manufacturing footprint. Production from the facility is expected to start in 2028.
The automotive facility will support Mahindra Auto’s next-generation platforms, including the NU_IQ architecture, and will be capable of manufacturing vehicles across multiple powertrains including internal combustion engine, electric vehicles and future technologies—for both domestic and global markets.
The supplier park at Sambhajinagar will strengthen the manufacturing value chain through closer partner collaboration, improved logistics efficiency, and enhanced localisation. It will supply components to the new Nagpur facility as well as Mahindra’s existing ones at Chakan and Nashik.
Published on  February 6, 2026

headline: Top Gainers & Losers: Hitachi Energy, MRF, Nykaa, HUL among top gainers
condensed_text: The Indian stock market turned into the green in Friday’s session on February 6 after a range-bound trade, supported by gains in FMCG and select private banking stocks, which helped offset losses in IT, pharma and auto shares. At its sixth and final bi-monthly monetary policy review for the current financial year, the central bank decided to retain the repo rate at 5.25% and maintained a neutral stance. In terms of sector-wise performance, Nifty FMCG led the gainers with a 2.27% surge, while Nifty Consumer Durables, Nifty Oil & Gas, and Nifty Realty also ended higher, posting gains of up to 1%. Vinod Nair, Head of Research, Geojit Investments Limited, said, "Domestic equity markets traded largely subdued through most of the session before staging a late recovery, supported by selective buying in FMCG and private banking stocks. However, markets had anticipated a mildly dovish undertone, which failed to materialise as the RBI retained its neutral stance, resulting in an uptick in India’s 10-year bond yields," he further added.
full_content:
The Indian stock market turned into the green in Friday’s session on February 6 after a range-bound trade, supported by gains in FMCG and select private banking stocks, which helped offset losses in IT, pharma and auto shares.
The Nifty 50 closed 0.20% higher at 25,693, while the S&P BSE Sensex ended 0.32% higher at 83,580. Both benchmark indices finished the week on a strong note, extending their winning streak to a second consecutive week.
Broader markets, however, were mixed. The Nifty Midcap 100 closed flat, while the Nifty Smallcap 100 declined 0.30%.
Meanwhile, the Reserve Bank of India kept policy interest rates unchanged. At its sixth and final bi-monthly monetary policy review for the current financial year, the central bank decided to retain the repo rate at 5.25% and maintained a neutral stance.
In terms of sector-wise performance, Nifty FMCG led the gainers with a 2.27% surge, while Nifty Consumer Durables, Nifty Oil & Gas, and Nifty Realty also ended higher, posting gains of up to 1%.
On the downside, Nifty IT emerged as the worst performer, slipping 1.47%, while Nifty Pharma remained under pressure, declining another 0.72%. Nifty Auto and Nifty PSU Bank were also among the laggards, with both indices falling 0.52% each.
Vinod Nair, Head of Research, Geojit Investments Limited, said, "Domestic equity markets traded largely subdued through most of the session before staging a late recovery, supported by selective buying in FMCG and private banking stocks. In contrast, the domestic IT sector continued to underperform."
"The RBI’s policy announcement was broadly in line with expectations, maintaining status quo on interest rates while reiterating a constructive growth outlook. However, markets had anticipated a mildly dovish undertone, which failed to materialise as the RBI retained its neutral stance, resulting in an uptick in India’s 10-year bond yields," he further added.
(More to come)

headline: Maruti Suzuki inks pact with Andhra Pradesh for four automated driving test tracks
condensed_text:
Hisashi Takeuchi, MD and CEO, Maruti Suzuki India
Maruti Suzuki India on Friday said it has inked a pact with Andhra Pradesh government for the setting up and maintenance of four automated driving test tracks across the state. The tracks will be set up at four Regional Transport Office (RTO) locations in the state, namely Eluru, Ongole, Vizianagaram, and Anakapalli. Aligned with his vision for technology-led solutions, we are honoured to bring 4 Automated Driving Test Tracks (ADTTs) to the state of Andhra Pradesh," Maruti Suzuki India MD and CEO Hisashi Takeuchi said in a statement. "The automation of driving test tracks is expected to bring greater uniformity and objectivity in the testing process and ensure that driving licenses are issued only to candidates with the requisite driving skills, thereby strengthening road safety in the state," Andhra Pradesh Transport Commissioner Manish Kumar Sinha stated. The ADTTs in Eluru, Vizianagaram, Ongole and Anakapalli will serve light motor vehicles and two-wheeler driving license applicants.
full_content:
Hisashi Takeuchi, MD and CEO, Maruti Suzuki India
Maruti Suzuki India on Friday said it has inked a pact with Andhra Pradesh government for the setting up and maintenance of four automated driving test tracks across the state.
The tracks will be set up at four Regional Transport Office (RTO) locations in the state, namely Eluru, Ongole, Vizianagaram, and Anakapalli.
Under the MoA, the car major will automate and maintain these driving test tracks for a period of three years from the date of commissioning.
"During my meeting with Chief Minister of Andhra Pradesh, Chandrababu Naidu, I was impressed by his love for technology. Aligned with his vision for technology-led solutions, we are honoured to bring 4 Automated Driving Test Tracks (ADTTs) to the state of Andhra Pradesh," Maruti Suzuki India MD and CEO Hisashi Takeuchi said in a statement.
ADTTs use advanced technology that ensure a comprehensive, efficient, and transparent process with zero human intervention, he added.
This guarantees that only skilled drivers are awarded a driving license, thereby improving overall road safety, Takeuchi noted.
"The automation of driving test tracks is expected to bring greater uniformity and objectivity in the testing process and ensure that driving licenses are issued only to candidates with the requisite driving skills, thereby strengthening road safety in the state," Andhra Pradesh Transport Commissioner Manish Kumar Sinha stated.
The ADTTs in Eluru, Vizianagaram, Ongole and Anakapalli will serve light motor vehicles and two-wheeler driving license applicants.
The track in Ongole will additionally serve Heavy Motor Vehicles (HMV) driving license applicants.
Published on  February 6, 2026

headline: Kalyan Jewellers India Q3 net profit nearly doubles YoY to Rs 416 crore; inventory gains help
condensed_text: Kalyan Jewellers India Q3 net profit nearly doubles YoY to Rs 416 crore; inventory gains help.
