The brokerage expects the margin to improve following the US decision to lower reciprocal tariffs on Indian exports from 25% to 18%, along with the removal of the additional punitive 25% tariff, which it believes will be margin-accretive.The brokerage expects growth momentum to sustain, particularly in North America, supported by a recovery in demand from telecom operators and hyperscalers, easing trade conditions, Sterlite Tech’s local manufacturing footprint, and a sharper focus on its data centre portfolio.As per Bloomberg consensus data, Sterlite Tech has a consensus rating of 4.33, with 66.7% of analysts recommending ‘Buy’ and the remaining 33.3% maintaining a ‘Hold’. headline: Maruti Suzuki ships 5.85 lakh cars by train in 2025; 26% of total dispatches
condensed_text: Maruti Suzuki India Ltd., on Monday, announced that the company dispatched more than 5.85 lakh vehicles through railways in 2025, 18% increase over 2024 and the company’s highest-ever annual rail dispatch.The share of rail in its total vehicle dispatches rose from 5.1% in 2016 to about 26% in 2025. Rail dispatch volumes have grown more than 7.5 times from nearly 77,000 units in 2016.The automaker said it avoided 87,904 metric tonnes of CO2e emissions and saved more than 687 lakh litres of fuel through rail transport.Hisashi Takeuchi, MD & CEO, said, “During the year, we strengthened our green logistic efforts through two landmark events – the inauguration of India’s largest automobile in-plant railway siding at our Manesar facility. Second, we dispatched vehicles by rail to the Kashmir valley through the world's highest railway arch bridge over the Chenab river, a first by any automobile manufacturer.”Read more: Maruti Suzuki cars cross world’s highest rail bridge to reach Anantnag in first batchTakeuchi added, “Our mid-term goal is to increase rail-based vehicle dispatches to 35% by FY31, contributing to India’s net-zero ambition by 2070.”Maruti Suzuki claims to be the first automobile company to obtain an AFTO licence in 2013. Since FY2014-15, it has transported over 28 lakh vehicles by rail from 22 destinations to more than 600 cities using a hub-and-spoke model.The company currently operates over 45 flexi deck rakes, each capable of carrying about 260 vehicles per trip. In 2025, rail dispatches from its in-plant railway sidings in Gujarat and Manesar accounted for 53% of its total rail dispatches.

Rail dispatch volumes have grown more than 7.5 times from nearly 77,000 units in 2016.The automaker said it avoided 87,904 metric tonnes of CO2e emissions and saved more than 687 lakh litres of fuel through rail transport.Hisashi Takeuchi, MD & CEO, said, “During the year, we strengthened our green logistic efforts through two landmark events – the inauguration of India’s largest automobile in-plant railway siding at our Manesar facility. headline: PGHL shares surge nearly 3% on strong Q3 results, special dividend
condensed_text:
iStockphoto
Procter & Gamble Health Limited shares jumped 2.91 per cent to ₹5,350 by midday Monday, following the company’s announcement of robust third-quarter results and a special dividend on Thursday. The stock opened at ₹5,274 and touched an intraday high of ₹5,429.50, with over 55 per cent of traded quantity delivered, indicating strong investor conviction. The Mumbai-based vitamins and supplements maker reported a 21 per cent surge in sales to ₹368 crore for the quarter ended December 31, 2025, compared to ₹310 crore in the same period last year. For the nine-month period, revenue climbed to ₹1,038 crore from ₹907 crore, while net profit increased to ₹232 crore against ₹190 crore year-on-year. The company reported earnings per share of ₹46.74 for the quarter, down from ₹54.76 in the previous year’s corresponding quarter, though nine-month EPS improved to ₹139.95.
full_content:
The stock opened at ₹5,274 and touched an intraday high of ₹5,429.50, with over 55% of traded quantity delivered, indicating strong investor conviction.
iStockphoto
Procter & Gamble Health Limited shares jumped 2.91 per cent to ₹5,350 by midday Monday, following the company’s announcement of robust third-quarter results and a special dividend on Thursday. The stock opened at ₹5,274 and touched an intraday high of ₹5,429.50, with over 55 per cent of traded quantity delivered, indicating strong investor conviction.
The Mumbai-based vitamins and supplements maker reported a 21 per cent surge in sales to ₹368 crore for the quarter ended December 31, 2025, compared to ₹310 crore in the same period last year. Profit after tax stood at ₹78 crore for the quarter. For the nine-month period, revenue climbed to ₹1,038 crore from ₹907 crore, while net profit increased to ₹232 crore against ₹190 crore year-on-year.
The board declared an interim dividend of ₹160 per share, including a one-time special dividend of ₹50 per share, payable by March 4, 2026. The record date for dividend eligibility is February 12, 2026.
Managing Director Milind Thatte attributed the growth to strategic initiatives including new product launches like Livogen Iron Gummies and Neurobion Nerve Pain Relief Cream, alongside strengthened supply chain capabilities. The company reported earnings per share of ₹46.74 for the quarter, down from ₹54.76 in the previous year’s corresponding quarter, though nine-month EPS improved to ₹139.95.
PGHL’s strong performance comes despite broader market headwinds, with the stock down 6.51 per cent year-to-date and 1.55 per cent over the past year. However, the three-year returns remain positive at 14.42 per cent. The company’s market capitalization stands at ₹8,881 crore.
Trading activity was robust with ₹16 crore worth of shares changing hands by noon. Buyers outnumbered sellers, with 52.91 per cent buy orders against 47.09 per cent sell orders, reflecting positive sentiment around the results and dividend announcement.
Published on  February 9, 2026
BACK TO TOP

headline: No buyback on the cards, but Shree Cement may raise dividend slightly, says HM Bangur
condensed_text: Shree Cement will not go in for a buyback but plans to raise its dividend slightly, Chairman HM Bangur said, adding that the fourth quarter’s numbers should be encouraging.The company's volume growth could touch 10% in the financial year ending March 2027 , higher than the industry average, according to Bangur. Now volumes have started coming, and value, which we had to sacrifice for volume for the last three quarters, that sacrifice part is over," he said.The company recently reported its October–December 2025 quarter results, where net profit rose 37.9% year-on-year to ₹266.7 crore, compared with ₹193.4 crore in the same period last year.Shree Cement currently has a market capitalisation of ₹96,443.84 crore. In terms of percentage, it will be 4 to 5%, but ₹10 to ₹15 is a good price rise.Q: Besides the volume growth being a bit of a disappointment, what's encouraging is that you have managed to bridge that price gap, let's say with UltraTech Cement. So, give and take everything, ₹150 to ₹200 price improvement in quarter four could be par for the course.A: Yes, of course, this will be about ₹150 to ₹200, and ₹1,200 EBITDA per tonne is not far off.Q: I want to ask you about the profitability. So, 4 to 5 million tonne of additional production is not going to matter much.Also Read | Cement, metals, banks: Dharmesh Kant’s playbook for the next 6–9 monthsQ: You believe everyone will prosper?A: Yes, we will also prosper.Q: What do you have to say about UltraTech Cement talking up the South industry?
full_content: Shree Cement will not go in for a buyback but plans to raise its dividend slightly, Chairman HM Bangur said, adding that the fourth quarter’s numbers should be encouraging.The company's volume growth could touch 10% in the financial year ending March 2027 , higher than the industry average, according to Bangur. However, the goal is “subject to the market growing at 8%,” he noted.“7% , and if the government's focus on infrastructure spending, as seen in the Budget, continues, we think the market can grow still faster. Overall, about 10% can be Shree Cement’s growth,” he added.The company has moved past its earlier strategy of prioritising value over volumes and has successfully narrowed pricing gaps with peers, he said.“This quarter, we will be getting both value and volume. Now volumes have started coming, and value, which we had to sacrifice for volume for the last three quarters, that sacrifice part is over," he said.The company recently reported its October–December 2025 quarter results, where net profit rose 37.9% year-on-year to ₹266.7 crore, compared with ₹193.4 crore in the same period last year.Shree Cement currently has a market capitalisation of ₹96,443.84 crore. The company’s shares have declined more than 4% over the past one year.These are edited excerpts of the interview.Q: In the last quarter, was the strategy the same, going for value over volume? What is the strategy from here on, what kind of volume growth are you estimating for quarter four, and what would that mean in terms of the yearly growth and for FY27? A: The strategy which we have been following for the last eight to nine months, that is almost through, and it has been successfully done. This quarter, we will be getting both value and volume. Now volumes have started coming, and value, which we had to sacrifice for volume for the last three quarters, that sacrifice part is over.Initially, the public and the dealers didn't expect that this could be sustainable. We were under pressure. But this quarter, for the first one and a half months, up to February 10, our volumes are definitely better than the same quarter last year. And it is a commodity; we don't know what will happen tomorrow. I will say very modest, a 5-8% jump in volume with a good jump in prices.Q: So, by the end of this year, you land closer to around, something in the vicinity of around 36 to 36.5 million tonne. Will that be a fair estimate?A: Yes, 36.5-37 million tonne will be the estimate.Q: What about prices? Your maximum exposure is in the North, followed by the East and then the South. What has been the price change on average for quarter four, if we compare it to quarter three? I understand that price increases have now been absorbed. A: Yes, we try to price multiple times. Sometimes it gets absorbed. But about a ₹10 to ₹15 price increase. In terms of percentage, it will be 4 to 5%, but ₹10 to ₹15 is a good price rise.Q: Besides the volume growth being a bit of a disappointment, what's encouraging is that you have managed to bridge that price gap, let's say with UltraTech Cement. Earlier, the price gap was around ₹30. That's down to around ₹15. So, are you satisfied on that front now? Also, could you tell us, observing that non-trade as a percentage of the mix had moved up, do you believe that this will reduce again, and you focus again on trade?A: The prices are different, but it creates so much margin, and there is so much distribution cost. So, in non-trade, the EBITDA is almost the same. So, trade or non-trade hardly makes a difference. Now, ₹13 to ₹15 is the fair estimate. This has come down, and now, as I was saying in the very first opening line, the volumes are also coming back. So now we will be having the best of both worlds.Q: And the best of both worlds means in quarter four, you get back to around ₹1,200 to ₹1,250 per tonne of EBITDA. Would that be a fair estimate? Why I'm asking you about that is, see, prices have gone up by around 3 to 4%, volume growth is going to come back. So, you'll have operating leverage. You'll also have pricing benefits and input costs - you have focused a lot out there. So, give and take everything, ₹150 to ₹200 price improvement in quarter four could be par for the course.A: Yes, of course, this will be about ₹150 to ₹200, and ₹1,200 EBITDA per tonne is not far off.Q: I want to ask you about the profitability. In the North, you have been strong with regard to market share and the way you're focused on cost as well. Could you tell us, what is the EBITDA per tonne difference if I compare the North and the South? A: The North would be relatively about ₹500 higher in comparison to the South.Q: But the problem is that in North India you will have a few more players coming. JSW Cement has shown some aggression. UltraTech is adding capacity, JK Cement as well as Wonder Cement. So, the Street believes that your dominance in North India is going to be challenged. What do you have to say to that?A: Yes, dominance in North India will definitely be challenged. Right now, if you have 20% market share, if you come down to 16%, that is alright. But the point is, our volumes will increase. The demand is much more. India, when it was growing at 7%, had 30 million tonne in North India. Now it is growing at 7% at 100 million tonne in North India. So, every year, demand will increase by 7 million tonne. So, 4 to 5 million tonne of additional production is not going to matter much.Also Read | Cement, metals, banks: Dharmesh Kant’s playbook for the next 6–9 monthsQ: You believe everyone will prosper?A: Yes, we will also prosper.Q: What do you have to say about UltraTech Cement talking up the South industry? They are saying the South is the new North. Do you believe, indeed, the South is doing better?A: Only about a minute back, I had said North Indian profits are ₹500 higher. In the future, nobody knows how it will turn out tomorrow. Yes, it may be possible, may not be possible, but we have to see. We don't say anything definitively.Q: You will have to do something to excite the Street. You're sitting on a good amount of cash, and in the past, you have said you want to grow organically. But with this cash that you have in the books, do you think you can give a higher dividend? If yes, how much does the dividend payout ratio go up by? Or do you think you could also look to consider a buyback?A: No, buyback will not be there. There is no requirement for a buyback. We will increase the dividend a little. And in the fourth quarter, things will be exciting. The numbers will excite. We don't have to keep exciting every quarter, every year, but this quarter will be good. That's all I can say.Q: You have narrowed the pricing gap with the leader and you're sounding far more optimistic in quarter four. So, what would be your estimate of volume growth for FY27?A: In FY26, we had grown less than the market. Yes, but in FY27, our growth will be higher than the average market growth. That's all I can say.Q: And you're expecting the market to grow at around 6 to 7%?A: 7%, and if the government's focus on infrastructure spending as seen in the Budget continues, we think the market can grow still faster. Overall, about 10% can be attributed to Shree Cement’s growth.Q: 10% growth for next year?A: Subject to the market growing at 8%.For the full interview, watch the accompanying videoCatch all the latest updates from the stock market here

headline: Man Industries shares rise over 7% after posting strong Q3 as profit jumps 62%, margin expands sharply
condensed_text: Man Industries shares rise over 7% after posting strong Q3 as profit jumps 62%, margin expands sharply. Shares of Man Industries  Ltd surged more than 7% on Monday, February 9, after the company reported a strong set of earnings for the December quarter, with a sharp improvement in profitability and margins, aided by operating leverage and higher execution.For Q3FY26, the company’s consolidated net profit rose 61.8% year-on-year to ₹55 crore from ₹34 crore in the same period last year. Revenue from operations increased 13.4% YoY to ₹830.4 crore from ₹732 crore.Operating performance improved significantly during the quarter, with EBITDA surging 62% year-on-year to ₹127.7 crore, compared with ₹79 crore in Q3FY25. EBITDA margin expanded to 15.4%, from 10.8% a year ago.Read more: Sterlite Tech surges over 8% on Nuvama Buy call and margin boost from tariff cutsOn a standalone basis, Man Industries reported a net profit of ₹60.9 crore for the quarter, up from ₹37.6 crore in the year-ago period. Revenue from operations stood at ₹803.5 crore, compared with ₹730.8 crore last year, while profit before tax rose to ₹81.7 crore from ₹50.3 crore.The company said its order book stood at approximately ₹4,005 crore as of the date, to be executed over the next 6 to 12 months, providing healthy revenue visibility.Man Industries operates primarily in the steel pipes segment and caters to domestic and international energy and infrastructure projects.Following the Q3 results announcement, shares of Man Industries hit an intraday high of ₹397.40, but the stock has since pared some of its gains and is currently trading 5.04% up at ₹381.65.

Revenue from operations increased 13.4% YoY to ₹830.4 crore from ₹732 crore.Operating performance improved significantly during the quarter, with EBITDA surging 62% year-on-year to ₹127.7 crore, compared with ₹79 crore in Q3FY25. EBITDA margin expanded to 15.4%, from 10.8% a year ago.Read more: Sterlite Tech surges over 8% on Nuvama Buy call and margin boost from tariff cutsOn a standalone basis, Man Industries reported a net profit of ₹60.9 crore for the quarter, up from ₹37.6 crore in the year-ago period. Revenue from operations stood at ₹803.5 crore, compared with ₹730.8 crore last year, while profit before tax rose to ₹81.7 crore from ₹50.3 crore.The company said its order book stood at approximately ₹4,005 crore as of the date, to be executed over the next 6 to 12 months, providing healthy revenue visibility.Man Industries operates primarily in the steel pipes segment and caters to domestic and international energy and infrastructure projects.Following the Q3 results announcement, shares of Man Industries hit an intraday high of ₹397.40, but the stock has since pared some of its gains and is currently trading 5.04% up at ₹381.65. The stock has rallied 39.72% in the past year.

headline: Sonata Software bets on healthcare, BFSI, and AI to drive next phase of growth
condensed_text: These businesses, built and scaled over the last few years, now contribute a meaningful share of both revenues and the order pipeline.Management remains optimistic about these segments, citing sustained demand and long-term deal visibility, which continues to offset softness in select client accounts.In the October–December quarter , Sonata Software reported revenue of ₹3,080 crore, profit of ₹104 crore, and margins of 5.21%.These are edited excerpts of the interview.Q: What about the AI led engagements? That's what we're seeing at this point in time.Q: I wanted to understand from a business standpoint, given the sort of conversations around AI, the new developments that are taking place globally as well, for a business like yours, what proportion of your revenue gets impacted by AI in the sense that AI capabilities can do that a lot better than what you are currently offering, or and concomitantly on your cost business, what proportion of AI can reduce your cost? But Sonata business is far more complex on modernisation and regulated industry perspective so we feel at this at this point in time, we are moving forward, embracing the changes that are happening in the industry, helping clients deliver faster, but really keeping a watchful eye on the future as well, because this technology still is evolving at this point in time.Q: In your third quarter numbers, there's a bit of a mixed bag when you look at the sectoral contribution. AI order book is increasing in a very healthy manner, which is much in line with their expectations.Now from a sectoral perspective, clearly we had large client issue in banking and a large client issue in Technology, Media and Telecom , so that's why the sectoral performances look not so good on those two sectors, just because of the two specific clients issue we had.In retail manufacturing, much in line what we have been saying, our tariff have been hitting us. So overall, very bullish about healthcare business, very bullish about where banking businesses, except for one client issue we have, and that's how the quarter came out for us.Q: Just for bookkeeping, if you could tell us a couple of things, the TMT, which is technology, media, telecom, HLS - healthcare and life sciences and RMD - retail, manufacturing, travel and distribution, how much do they contribute in terms of your current revenue, and what is their contribution in terms of your order book?
full_content: Artificial Intelligence-led engagements are emerging as a key growth driver for Bengaluru-based technology services company Sonata Software, with AI now forming a steadily rising share of its order book.Samir Dhir, MD & CEO, Sonata Software, highlighted that demand is increasingly centred on using AI to accelerate delivery timelines and improving productivity, particularly in complex modernisation programmes. This is helping the company execute projects faster without diluting pricing, supporting margin stability even in a cautious global tech spending environment.Beyond AI, the company’s forward outlook is anchored in structurally strong and regulated verticals such as healthcare and BFSI. These businesses, built and scaled over the last few years, now contribute a meaningful share of both revenues and the order pipeline.Management remains optimistic about these segments, citing sustained demand and long-term deal visibility, which continues to offset softness in select client accounts.In the October–December quarter , Sonata Software reported revenue of ₹3,080 crore, profit of ₹104 crore, and margins of 5.21%.These are edited excerpts of the interview.Q: What about the AI led engagements? They are now about 14% of your order book versus 10% is what you told us the quarter before. How do you see this mix rising over the year? What kind of contributions do you see from this segment and which verticals are driving up the demand for AI?A: We are not surprised with this, we have talked about it earlier. We said in three years, we think our AI order book should be around 20-25% and we are getting this sooner than we anticipated, which is nice. It's a secular trend that we see across our clients. Clients are asking us to use AI to deliver time to market faster. So as an example, one of our clients we're doing work, which is a modernisation program, they wanted to they wanted to move from an older platform to a new technology, which probably would have taken about 12 to 15 months in prior times. But because our teams could bring in the agentic thinking and the AI thinking into the program, we are able to deliver in about 30 to 40% lesser time than we have had anticipated before.Now the price of the project is still the same, but you're just delivering that in an accelerated manner, because the tools exist today to deliver time to market faster. So, bulk of the changes in the project that we are seeing in our 14% order book that you mentioned, they are in the realm of delivering customers faster outcomes in a faster timeline basis, then really impact on the topline. That's what we're seeing at this point in time.Q: I wanted to understand from a business standpoint, given the sort of conversations around AI, the new developments that are taking place globally as well, for a business like yours, what proportion of your revenue gets impacted by AI in the sense that AI capabilities can do that a lot better than what you are currently offering, or and concomitantly on your cost business, what proportion of AI can reduce your cost? So, what the net impact of artificial intelligence could be in terms of replaced and incremental revenue and replaced and incremental costs?A: We are a specialist firm in modernisation engineering. Generally speaking, we move customers from old technologies to newer platforms, and we do that in a very regulated industry model, which is banking, financial services, healthcare. They are highly regulated industries, there is a lot of premium on data sensitivity. There's a lot of premium on understanding the context of the old code bases and then migrating them to the newer platforms.At this point in time, candidly, we don't see a significant impact of any of the tools that even got launched last week or even prior, impacting that modernisation type of work that we end up doing for our customers. Having said that, it's an area that we are watching, we remain watchful. We do see productivity benefits coming out of AI, much in line with our industry peers, and that's what we are seeing. But in general, the demand from our customers and all the automobile that we talked to you about is to go faster, but not cheaper. That's not what we're seeing at this point in time.And because we are largely operating regulated industry environment, we don't believe the tools that are being launched right now have an impact on those industry segments. But Sonata business is far more complex on modernisation and regulated industry perspective so we feel at this at this point in time, we are moving forward, embracing the changes that are happening in the industry, helping clients deliver faster, but really keeping a watchful eye on the future as well, because this technology still is evolving at this point in time.Q: In your third quarter numbers, there's a bit of a mixed bag when you look at the sectoral contribution. On one hand, you had retail healthcare grow despite you telling us previously that tariffs had impacted the retail sector. BFSI continues to come down, telecom, media, technology, also, it stayed soft in the quarter. Now, as you are closing the year, if you could give us a guidance on what the full year FY26 growth would look like, and where are the segments where you are continuing to see ramped down by clients?A: Overall, we had a good quarter. We delivered PAT growth of profit after tax, growth of 21.4% year-on-year, and a sequential growth of 6.1% so we are very pleased with the performance that in this environment we could deliver 20% plus PAT growth year-on-year basis. Our earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation  outside the one time exception that we would take because of the labour code, also accreted in the quarter, from 17.3% a quarter prior to about 19.5% in this quarter. Overall, from a profitability perspective, had a very solid, robust performance, and much in line with what we have guided earlier, that we want to be a high-teens and a low 20s EBITDA company, so very good with that.On the domestic business as well, we had a pretty strong showing. Our gross contribution improved quarter-on-quarter basis, 10.8% which was a concern that we all had given the Microsoft and some of the larger OEM going direct issue. I think we delivered a seasonally strong quarter on the SITL as well. And you are right I think from a AI perspective, we have been making steady progress. Our order book for the quarter was about 14% of the total order book. AI order book is increasing in a very healthy manner, which is much in line with their expectations.Now from a sectoral perspective, clearly we had large client issue in banking and a large client issue in Technology, Media and Telecom , so that's why the sectoral performances look not so good on those two sectors, just because of the two specific clients issue we had.In retail manufacturing, much in line what we have been saying, our tariff have been hitting us. There is some one-time benefit we got in the quarter, but I think going into next quarter will continue to see retail manufacturing will be not growing to the extent that you saw in the in the current quarter. So overall, very bullish about healthcare business, very bullish about where banking businesses, except for one client issue we have, and that's how the quarter came out for us.Q: Just for bookkeeping, if you could tell us a couple of things, the TMT, which is technology, media, telecom, HLS - healthcare and life sciences and RMD - retail, manufacturing, travel and distribution, how much do they contribute in terms of your current revenue, and what is their contribution in terms of your order book? So that we get a trend on where this is likely to go from here onA: Healthcare, life sciences and banking, financials, is the new verticals we created about three, four years back, they contribute about 9% of our total business back in 2023, they contribute now roughly about 30% of our business together, BFSI and healthcare together. Bulk of our out of book, I would say 60 to 70% order book continues to be in these two verticals. And that trend, we think is a secular trend that we will continue to see.TMT outside the large client is a smaller book of business and retail manufacturing, like we mentioned earlier, is under pressure because of the whole tariff situation that is currently going on. It will probably just hold flat to what you are seeing at this point in time. That's our current expectation.Sonata Software’s current market capitalisation is ₹8,660.92 crore. The stock is currently trading at ₹309.75 as of 11:14 pm on the NSE and has declined 33% over the last year.Follow our live blog for more stock market updatesFollow our live blog for more updates on Q3 results

headline: Kalyan Jewellers, Vaibhav Global, Thangamayil, Senco, PN Gadgil & Goldiam jump up to 15%; here's why
condensed_text: Kalyan Jewellers, Vaibhav Global, Thangamayil, Senco, PN Gadgil & Goldiam jump up to 15%; here's why. Shares of several gems and jewellery companies jumped sharply in Monday’s session, climbing up to 15 per cent, after an interim trade agreement between India and the US boosted investor sentiment. Stocks such as Vaibhav Global Ltd , Goldiam International Ltd, Kalyan Jewellers India Ltd , Thangamayil Jewellery Ltd , PN Gadgil Jewellers Ltd and Senco Gold Ltd witnessed strong buying interest during the session. At last check, shares of Vaibhav Global, Goldiam International and Kalyan Jewellers were up 14.90 per cent, 13.51 per cent and 12.02 per cent, respectively. Thangamayil Jewellery gained 6.08 per cent, while P N Gadgil Jewellers and Senco Gold advanced 5.38 per cent and 4.40 per cent, respectively.
full_content:
Shares of several gems and jewellery companies jumped sharply in Monday’s session, climbing up to 15 per cent, after an interim trade agreement between India and the US boosted investor sentiment.
Stocks such as Vaibhav Global Ltd , Goldiam International Ltd, Kalyan Jewellers India Ltd , Thangamayil Jewellery Ltd , PN Gadgil Jewellers Ltd and Senco Gold Ltd witnessed strong buying interest during the session.
At last check, shares of Vaibhav Global, Goldiam International and Kalyan Jewellers were up 14.90 per cent, 13.51 per cent and 12.02 per cent, respectively. Thangamayil Jewellery gained 6.08 per cent, while P N Gadgil Jewellers and Senco Gold advanced 5.38 per cent and 4.40 per cent, respectively.
Some market analysts attributed the strong uptick to a combination of improving sentiment following the India–US interim trade deal and a recent correction in gold prices from record highs.
Kranthi Bathini, Equity Strategist at WealthMills Securities, said some buying interest is emerging in physical gold jewellers as the precious metal has corrected from its peak. He added that the India–US trade deal has also lifted sentiment, which is reflected in the rise in jewellery stocks.
G Chokkalingam, Managing Director – Research at Equinomics, said high precious metal prices are expected to reduce jewellery demand, leading to a negative short-term outlook. He added that jewellers with substantial inventories of gold bought at lower prices a few months ago could use those stocks to deliver better performance in the near term.
Meanwhile, domestic equity benchmarks were trading higher, gaining around 0.5 per cent, supported by positive global cues. The broader market outperformed the frontline indices, with the Nifty Midcap index rising 1.29 per cent and the Nifty Smallcap index surging 2.08 per cent.
Copyright © 2026 Living Media India Limited. For reprint rights: Syndications Today. India Today Group.

headline: Maruti dispatches record 5.85 lakh vehicles via railways in 2025
condensed_text:
Members of a Maruti Suzuki dealership unload cars from a freight train
-
Maruti Suzuki India on Monday said it dispatched over 5.85 lakh cars through railways last year, an year-on-year growth of 18 per cent over 2024. The auto major said its share of rail mode in outbound logistics has grown exponentially, rising from 5.1 per cent in 2016 to 26 per cent in 2025, significantly reducing carbon emissions, country's oil imports and easing road congestion. "During the year, we strengthened our green logistic efforts through two landmark events– the inauguration of India's largest automobile in-plant railway siding at our Manesar facility, and second was we dispatched vehicles by rail to Kashmir valley through the world's highest railway arch bridge over Chenab river, a first by any automobile manufacturer," Maruti Suzuki India MD and CEO Hisashi Takeuchi said in a statement. The company's mid-term goal is to increase rail-based vehicle dispatches to 35 per cent by FY 2030-31, contributing to India's net-zero ambition by 2070, he added. In CY 2025, rail dispatches from the company's in-plant railway siding at Gujarat and Manesar facility accounted for 53 per cent of its total rail dispatches.
full_content:
Members of a Maruti Suzuki dealership unload cars from a freight train
-
Maruti Suzuki India on Monday said it dispatched over 5.85 lakh cars through railways last year, an year-on-year growth of 18 per cent over 2024.
The auto major said its share of rail mode in outbound logistics has grown exponentially, rising from 5.1 per cent in 2016 to 26 per cent in 2025, significantly reducing carbon emissions, country's oil imports and easing road congestion.
"During the year, we strengthened our green logistic efforts through two landmark events– the inauguration of India's largest automobile in-plant railway siding at our Manesar facility, and second was we dispatched vehicles by rail to Kashmir valley through the world's highest railway arch bridge over Chenab river, a first by any automobile manufacturer," Maruti Suzuki India MD and CEO Hisashi Takeuchi said in a statement.
The company's mid-term goal is to increase rail-based vehicle dispatches to 35 per cent by FY 2030-31, contributing to India's net-zero ambition by 2070, he added.
Since FY 2014-15, Maruti Suzuki has transported over 28 lakh vehicles from 22 destinations servicing over 600 cities pan India through a hub and spoke model.
Currently, the car market leader uses over 45 flexi deck rakes, each with a capacity of carrying around 260 vehicles per trip.
In CY 2025, rail dispatches from the company's in-plant railway siding at Gujarat and Manesar facility accounted for 53 per cent of its total rail dispatches.
Published on  February 9, 2026
BACK TO TOP

headline: Adani Enterprises receives information request from US sanctions watchdog OFAC
condensed_text: Adani Enterprises Limited on Tuesday, February 10, said it has voluntarily engaged with the US Office of Foreign Assets Control  and has received a Request for Information  from the US regulator as part of a civil investigation linked to allegations flagged in a Wall Street Journal article last year.In an exchange filing, Adani Enterprises said the RFI was received through its counsel on February 4, 2026 , following discussions initiated by the company with OFAC in connection with allegations raised in a Wall Street Journal article published on June 2, 2025.The company said the RFI indicates that OFAC is conducting a civil investigation into certain transactions processed through US financial institutions that may have involved, directly or indirectly, Iran or entities subject to US sanctions against Iran. The period under review spans from June 2023 to the present.Adani Enterprises emphasised that the engagement with OFAC is voluntary and part of its effort to cooperate transparently with the US authorities. The company said it will provide the information sought under the RFI and continue to fully cooperate with the regulator.In its disclosure, Adani Enterprises said there are no findings, penalties, sanctions, or restrictions imposed on the company at this stage. LPG formed a “very small and operationally non-material” part of its business, contributing about 1.46% of Adani Enterprises’ revenue and around 0.5% of the Adani Group’s overall revenue in FY25. As a precautionary step, the company said it had already ceased all LPG imports with effect from June 2, 2025.Adani Enterprises clarified that the disclosure is being made in compliance with Regulation 30 of the SEBI Listing Regulations and requested stock exchanges to take the information on record.
full_content: Adani Enterprises Limited on Tuesday, February 10, said it has voluntarily engaged with the US Office of Foreign Assets Control  and has received a Request for Information  from the US regulator as part of a civil investigation linked to allegations flagged in a Wall Street Journal article last year.In an exchange filing, Adani Enterprises said the RFI was received through its counsel on February 4, 2026 , following discussions initiated by the company with OFAC in connection with allegations raised in a Wall Street Journal article published on June 2, 2025.The company said the RFI indicates that OFAC is conducting a civil investigation into certain transactions processed through US financial institutions that may have involved, directly or indirectly, Iran or entities subject to US sanctions against Iran. The period under review spans from June 2023 to the present.Adani Enterprises emphasised that the engagement with OFAC is voluntary and part of its effort to cooperate transparently with the US authorities. The company said it will provide the information sought under the RFI and continue to fully cooperate with the regulator.In its disclosure, Adani Enterprises said there are no findings, penalties, sanctions, or restrictions imposed on the company at this stage. It added that the communication from OFAC does not identify any aberrations or non-compliances.On the potential financial impact, the company said it does not expect any material implications. LPG formed a “very small and operationally non-material” part of its business, contributing about 1.46% of Adani Enterprises’ revenue and around 0.5% of the Adani Group’s overall revenue in FY25. As a precautionary step, the company said it had already ceased all LPG imports with effect from June 2, 2025.Adani Enterprises clarified that the disclosure is being made in compliance with Regulation 30 of the SEBI Listing Regulations and requested stock exchanges to take the information on record.

headline: Dixon Technologies hires former Zetwerk electronics head Josh Foulger
condensed_text:
Josh Foulger
Manufacturing unicorn Zetwerk's electronics business head Josh Foulger has resigned from the company and joined a subsidiary of its competitor Dixon Technologies, according to a regulatory filing. "Josh Foulger has been appointed as President- IT Hardware and New Projects in Padget Electronics Private Limited (PEPL), Wholly Owned/ Unlisted Material Subsidiary of Dixon, who shall assume the office with effect from 16th February, 2026," Dixon Technologies said in a regulatory filing. He joins PEPL from Zetwerk, where as CEO of Electronics, he led the division’s rapid expansion into new manufacturing verticals and successfully integrated key acquisitions to drive significant growth,” the filing said 	 Last month Zetwerk chief marketing officer Amrit Raj resigned from the company and joined venture capital firm Jungle Ventures. When contacted, Zetwerk Spokesperson said, "Josh Foulger has been instrumental in shaping Zetwerk Electronics during its early and growth stages. As he has decided to move back to Chennai for personal reasons, we thank him for his contribution and wish him the very best for his future endeavours.” 	 Zetwerk has earmarked Rs 1,000 crore investment for expanding its electronic manufacturing capacity in 2024 after Foulger took over the role.
full_content:
Josh Foulger
Manufacturing unicorn Zetwerk's electronics business head Josh Foulger has resigned from the company and joined a subsidiary of its competitor Dixon Technologies, according to a regulatory filing.
This is the second high profile exit from the company within a month ahead of its planned initial public offer.
"Josh Foulger has been appointed as President- IT Hardware and New Projects in Padget Electronics Private Limited (PEPL), Wholly Owned/ Unlisted Material Subsidiary of Dixon, who shall assume the office with effect from 16th February, 2026," Dixon Technologies said in a regulatory filing.
Foulger has exited Zetwerk within two years of joining the company. He previously headed Foxconn’s India business unit, Bharat FIH.
"Foulger is a seasoned industry veteran with over 30 years of global experience in Electronics System Design & Manufacturing (ESDM). He joins PEPL from Zetwerk, where as CEO of Electronics, he led the division’s rapid expansion into new manufacturing verticals and successfully integrated key acquisitions to drive significant growth,” the filing said 	 Last month Zetwerk chief marketing officer Amrit Raj resigned from the company and joined venture capital firm Jungle Ventures.
When contacted, Zetwerk Spokesperson said, "Josh Foulger has been instrumental in shaping Zetwerk Electronics during its early and growth stages. As he has decided to move back to Chennai for personal reasons, we thank him for his contribution and wish him the very best for his future endeavours.” 	 Zetwerk has earmarked Rs 1,000 crore investment for expanding its electronic manufacturing capacity in 2024 after Foulger took over the role.
The company said it is in discussion with bankers and expected to file draft papers for the IPO soon.
Zetwerk's last disclosed valuation was over USD 3.1 billion, while gross merchandise value scaled from about USD 100 million to more than USD 2 billion.
Published on  February 10, 2026
BACK TO TOP

headline: ACME Solar secures 220 MW solar-battery project in Madhya Pradesh
condensed_text: ACME Solar Holdings Ltd has received a letter of award from Rewa Ultra Mega Solar Limited for a 220 MW solar project with battery energy storage system at Morena Solar Park in Madhya Pradesh. The project forms part of a 440 MW tender floated by RUMSL under tariff-based competitive bidding guidelines, with the e-reverse auction conducted in September 2025. The project requires power supply with a maximum annual capacity utilization factor of 35 per cent, along with four hours of peak supply at 95 percent annual availability. ACME Solar currently operates a portfolio of 8,071 MW across solar, wind, storage and hybrid solutions, with 2,966 MW operational contracted capacity and 5,105 MW under construction. The shares of ACME Solar Holdings Ltd were trading at ₹233.4 up by ₹75.44 or 2.39 per cent on the NSE in the early trade today.
full_content:
ACME Solar Holdings Ltd has received a letter of award from Rewa Ultra Mega Solar Limited for a 220 MW solar project with battery energy storage system at Morena Solar Park in Madhya Pradesh. The project, awarded at a tariff of Rs 2.764 per unit, is scheduled for commercial operation by December 31, 2027.
The project forms part of a 440 MW tender floated by RUMSL under tariff-based competitive bidding guidelines, with the e-reverse auction conducted in September 2025. The 25-year power purchase agreement will be signed with Madhya Pradesh Power Management Company Limited and RUMSL.
The project requires power supply with a maximum annual capacity utilization factor of 35 per cent, along with four hours of peak supply at 95 percent annual availability. Peak supply includes two hours each during morning and evening periods. The solar plant will provide charging energy for evening peaks, while the procurer will supply morning peak energy free of cost during night hours.
RUMSL will provide land and evacuation infrastructure above 33 kV level as part of solar park facilities. The project will benefit from reduced GST rates and must comply with ALMM List-I requirements.
ACME Solar currently operates a portfolio of 8,071 MW across solar, wind, storage and hybrid solutions, with 2,966 MW operational contracted capacity and 5,105 MW under construction.
The shares of ACME Solar Holdings Ltd were trading at ₹233.4 up by ₹75.44 or 2.39 per cent on the NSE in the early trade today.
Published on  February 10, 2026

Buy, TP Raised to Rs 7653

NFIL has commissioned multiple projects (R32, HFO, Ag-chem) over past 3 years with its gross block increasing by >4x vs FY22.
Some of these capacities have ramped up with rest expected to be ramped up over the next couple of years.

stellar Q3FY26 showing was backed by growth in all three segments with specialty chemicals surpassing expectations especially in a challenging agrochemical industry. headline: Lupin clears patent hurdle with Astellas Pharma, keeps Mirabegron sales in US
condensed_text:
Lupin said on Tuesday it agreed ‌to a $90 million settlement ​with Japan's
Astellas Pharma in a patent dispute over the bladder
disorder drug Mirabegron, a move that allows it to continue
selling the product in the United States. Under the agreement, Lupin ​and its U.S. unit will pay
Astellas ⁠a $75 million upfront payment and per-unit licensing
fees on Mirabegron sales through September 2027, the ​company
said in ⁠an exchange filing. In a separate statement, the Japanese drugmaker said the
settlement concludes its litigation with Lupin and ‌added that it
is reviewing the ‌potential financial impact for the fiscal year
ending March 31, 2026. Lupin ‍had previously disclosed the patent dispute with
Astellas last April over its generic ‍version of Myrbetriq,
Astellas' overactive bladder drug, after a U.S. court ruling
raised the risk that generic versions could be withdrawn from
the market. Citi analysts said the settlement removes legal uncertainty
around Lupin's Mirabegron sales in the U.S. ⁠and could delay the
entry of other generic rivals, potentially providing ​Lupin and
Zydus Lifesciences, another drugmaker involved in ⁠the
litigation, with a period of limited competition.
full_content:
Lupin said on Tuesday it agreed ‌to a $90 million settlement ​with Japan's
Astellas Pharma in a patent dispute over the bladder
disorder drug Mirabegron, a move that allows it to continue
selling the product in the United States.
Under the agreement, Lupin ​and its U.S. unit will pay
Astellas ⁠a $75 million upfront payment and per-unit licensing
fees on Mirabegron sales through September 2027, the ​company
said in ⁠an exchange filing.
In a separate statement, the Japanese drugmaker said the
settlement concludes its litigation with Lupin and ‌added that it
is reviewing the ‌potential financial impact for the fiscal year
ending March 31, 2026.
Lupin ‍had previously disclosed the patent dispute with
Astellas last April over its generic ‍version of Myrbetriq,
Astellas' overactive bladder drug, after a U.S. court ruling
raised the risk that generic versions could be withdrawn from
the market.
Citi analysts said the settlement removes legal uncertainty
around Lupin's Mirabegron sales in the U.S. ⁠and could delay the
entry of other generic rivals, potentially providing ​Lupin and
Zydus Lifesciences, another drugmaker involved in ⁠the
litigation, with a period of limited competition.
Lupin's shares were trading up 0.91%, as of 11:01 am IST.
Published on  February 10, 2026
BACK TO TOP

headline: Why TCS, CUB, Marico, GRSE, Shree Refrigerations, HAL, Ceigall, Godrej Agrovet, Axiscades, Anant Raj, UVS Hospitality to remain active in today’s trade
condensed_text: Why TCS, CUB, Marico, GRSE, Shree Refrigerations, HAL, Ceigall, Godrej Agrovet, Axiscades, Anant Raj, UVS Hospitality to remain active in today’s trade. TCS partners with Redzone to modernise mid-market manufacturing, City Union Bank names R Vijay Anandh as MD, Marico SEA buys Skinetiq, while GRSE, Shree Refrigerations, Ceigall, Axiscades, and Submer announce key strategic wins. Marico South East Asia Corporation (MSEA), a wholly owned subsidiary of Marico Ltd , has announced that its subsidiary has entered into an agreement to acquire a majority stake in a Vietnam-based skin care company, Skinetiq, according to an exchange filing. Garden Reach Shipbuilders & Engineers (GRSE) Ltd and Hindustan Shipyard Limited (HSL) have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) to form a consortium aimed at undertaking a large-scale, strategically significant national shipbuilding programme. Axiscades Technologies, a chip-to-product company and a pioneer in Aerospace, Defence, Electronics, Semiconductor, and Artificial Intelligence (ESAI), headquartered in Bangalore, India, has announced a new win for its subsidiary, Mistral Solutions, in the Defence division.
full_content:
TCS partners with Redzone to modernise mid-market manufacturing, City Union Bank names R Vijay Anandh as MD, Marico SEA buys Skinetiq, while GRSE, Shree Refrigerations, Ceigall, Axiscades, and Submer announce key strategic wins.
Redzone, a company in manufacturing and supply chains, has announced a strategic partnership with Tata Consultancy Services (TCS ). Together, they will help mid-market manufacturers modernise operations faster, scale execution with confidence, and unlock the full value of AI without the excessive cost, disruption, time and staffing associated with traditional ERP programs.
City Union Bank has said that the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) had approved the appointment of R Vijay Anandh, currently the Executive Director (ED) at the private bank, as the next Managing Director & CEO. Anandh holds over 28 years of experience in banking, risk management, Portfolio Analysis, Credit Appraisals, and other retail banking segments. Prior to his appointment at City Union Bank, he served as the Business and Collections Head for Retail Asset products at RBL Bank, working closely with the ED & the MD there.
Marico South East Asia Corporation (MSEA), a wholly owned subsidiary of Marico Ltd , has announced that its subsidiary has entered into an agreement to acquire a majority stake in a Vietnam-based skin care company, Skinetiq, according to an exchange filing. Under the agreement, MSEA will acquire a 75% stake in Skinetiq for about ₹261.6 crore (or 750 billion Vietnamese Dong) in two tranches.
Garden Reach Shipbuilders & Engineers (GRSE) Ltd and Hindustan Shipyard Limited (HSL) have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) to form a consortium aimed at undertaking a large-scale, strategically significant national shipbuilding programme. The partnership envisages the construction of advanced maritime platforms and is expected to enhance the country’s maritime infrastructure, technological self-reliance, and long-term operational capabilities.
Shree Refrigerations Limited (SRL) has secured multiple fresh orders worth more than Rs 40 Crore in the last 2 months, from the Indian Navy, reinforcing its strong position in the defence segment. These orders predominantly pertain to retrofitting/upgrading existing equipment with newer, higher-performance equipment and replenishing spare parts for earlier-installed equipment. With the addition of these orders, SRL’s total closing order book is now more than ₹320 crore (excluding GST), providing strong medium-term revenue visibility and supporting sustained business growth.
The board of UVS Hospitality and Services Ltd, formerly known as Thirdwave Financial Intermediaries Ltd, will meet on February 14 to consider a comprehensive capital raising plan and the strategic acquisition of Calcio Restaurants Private Ltd. Following the execution of a term sheet in late 2025, the Board will now formally deliberate on the acquisition of Calcio Restaurants Private Limited. The transaction is proposed via a Share Swap arrangement, where equity shares of UVS Hospitality will be issued to Calcio’s shareholders.
Ceigall India has secured a significant Letter of Award (LOA) worth approximately ₹1,700 crore from Rewa Ultra Mega Solar Ltd. The project involves developing a 220 MW solar power plant integrated with Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) at Morena Solar Park in Madhya Pradesh. This award enhances the company’s future revenue visibility and solidifies its presence in the renewable energy infrastructure sector, with a tariff of ₹2.70/kWh.
Godrej Agrovet Ltd has launched a new insecticide, TAKAI, developed for rice crops. Powered by Cyclapryn technology developed by ISK Japan, TAKAI is effective against key rice pests, Stem Borer, and controls Leaf Folder. When applied at 160 ml at 15-30 Days After Transplant (DAT) and again at 40-60 DAT, it provides a broad protection window for the rice crop. The company is in the process of obtaining label approval for TAKAI in Maize, Chilli, Cabbage, Soybean, Chickpea, and Sugarcane crops as well.
Axiscades Technologies, a chip-to-product company and a pioneer in Aerospace, Defence, Electronics, Semiconductor, and Artificial Intelligence (ESAI), headquartered in Bangalore, India, has announced a new win for its subsidiary, Mistral Solutions, in the Defence division. Mistral Solutions, a leader in high-performance embedded systems and defence electronics, today announced the receipt of an order valued at approximately ₹80 crore under the prestigious LCA Mk1A programme of Hindustan Aeronautics Ltd (HAL).
Submer, the full-stack AI infrastructure provider, has announced a strategic collaboration with Anant Raj Cloud, a subsidiary of Anant Raj Limited, to develop fully operational AI-ready data centres across India. The collaboration enables the rapid deployment of high-density, energy-efficient computing platforms designed to support sovereign and enterprise AI workloads at scale. This partnership serves as a primary example of the EU-India Trade Deal in action, bringing world-class liquid-cooling technology from Spain and combining it with India’s robust infrastructure and operational support. Crucially, the collaboration strengthens a single, accountable source for AI data centre design, build, and scalable operation. Combined with Submer’s neocloud and inference platform, InferX, the partnership enables customers to access AI-ready infrastructure and compute through a unified, end-to-end model aligned with India’s sovereignty requirements.
Published on  February 10, 2026
BACK TO TOP

headline: Why TCS, CUB, Marico, GRSE, Shree Refrigerations, HAL, Ceigall, Godrej Agrovet, Axiscades, Anant Raj, UVS Hospitality to remain active in today’s trade
condensed_text: Why TCS, CUB, Marico, GRSE, Shree Refrigerations, HAL, Ceigall, Godrej Agrovet, Axiscades, Anant Raj, UVS Hospitality to remain active in today’s trade. TCS partners with Redzone to modernise mid-market manufacturing, City Union Bank names R Vijay Anandh as MD, Marico SEA buys Skinetiq, while GRSE, Shree Refrigerations, Ceigall, Axiscades, and Submer announce key strategic wins. Marico South East Asia Corporation (MSEA), a wholly owned subsidiary of Marico Ltd , has announced that its subsidiary has entered into an agreement to acquire a majority stake in a Vietnam-based skin care company, Skinetiq, according to an exchange filing. Garden Reach Shipbuilders & Engineers (GRSE) Ltd and Hindustan Shipyard Limited (HSL) have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) to form a consortium aimed at undertaking a large-scale, strategically significant national shipbuilding programme. Axiscades Technologies, a chip-to-product company and a pioneer in Aerospace, Defence, Electronics, Semiconductor, and Artificial Intelligence (ESAI), headquartered in Bangalore, India, has announced a new win for its subsidiary, Mistral Solutions, in the Defence division.
full_content:
TCS partners with Redzone to modernise mid-market manufacturing, City Union Bank names R Vijay Anandh as MD, Marico SEA buys Skinetiq, while GRSE, Shree Refrigerations, Ceigall, Axiscades, and Submer announce key strategic wins.
Redzone, a company in manufacturing and supply chains, has announced a strategic partnership with Tata Consultancy Services (TCS ). Together, they will help mid-market manufacturers modernise operations faster, scale execution with confidence, and unlock the full value of AI without the excessive cost, disruption, time and staffing associated with traditional ERP programs.
City Union Bank has said that the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) had approved the appointment of R Vijay Anandh, currently the Executive Director (ED) at the private bank, as the next Managing Director & CEO. Anandh holds over 28 years of experience in banking, risk management, Portfolio Analysis, Credit Appraisals, and other retail banking segments. Prior to his appointment at City Union Bank, he served as the Business and Collections Head for Retail Asset products at RBL Bank, working closely with the ED & the MD there.
Marico South East Asia Corporation (MSEA), a wholly owned subsidiary of Marico Ltd , has announced that its subsidiary has entered into an agreement to acquire a majority stake in a Vietnam-based skin care company, Skinetiq, according to an exchange filing. Under the agreement, MSEA will acquire a 75% stake in Skinetiq for about ₹261.6 crore (or 750 billion Vietnamese Dong) in two tranches.
Garden Reach Shipbuilders & Engineers (GRSE) Ltd and Hindustan Shipyard Limited (HSL) have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) to form a consortium aimed at undertaking a large-scale, strategically significant national shipbuilding programme. The partnership envisages the construction of advanced maritime platforms and is expected to enhance the country’s maritime infrastructure, technological self-reliance, and long-term operational capabilities.
Shree Refrigerations Limited (SRL) has secured multiple fresh orders worth more than Rs 40 Crore in the last 2 months, from the Indian Navy, reinforcing its strong position in the defence segment. These orders predominantly pertain to retrofitting/upgrading existing equipment with newer, higher-performance equipment and replenishing spare parts for earlier-installed equipment. With the addition of these orders, SRL’s total closing order book is now more than ₹320 crore (excluding GST), providing strong medium-term revenue visibility and supporting sustained business growth.
The board of UVS Hospitality and Services Ltd, formerly known as Thirdwave Financial Intermediaries Ltd, will meet on February 14 to consider a comprehensive capital raising plan and the strategic acquisition of Calcio Restaurants Private Ltd. Following the execution of a term sheet in late 2025, the Board will now formally deliberate on the acquisition of Calcio Restaurants Private Limited. The transaction is proposed via a Share Swap arrangement, where equity shares of UVS Hospitality will be issued to Calcio’s shareholders.
Ceigall India has secured a significant Letter of Award (LOA) worth approximately ₹1,700 crore from Rewa Ultra Mega Solar Ltd. The project involves developing a 220 MW solar power plant integrated with Battery Energy Storage Systems (BESS) at Morena Solar Park in Madhya Pradesh. This award enhances the company’s future revenue visibility and solidifies its presence in the renewable energy infrastructure sector, with a tariff of ₹2.70/kWh.
Godrej Agrovet Ltd has launched a new insecticide, TAKAI, developed for rice crops. Powered by Cyclapryn technology developed by ISK Japan, TAKAI is effective against key rice pests, Stem Borer, and controls Leaf Folder. When applied at 160 ml at 15-30 Days After Transplant (DAT) and again at 40-60 DAT, it provides a broad protection window for the rice crop. The company is in the process of obtaining label approval for TAKAI in Maize, Chilli, Cabbage, Soybean, Chickpea, and Sugarcane crops as well.
Axiscades Technologies, a chip-to-product company and a pioneer in Aerospace, Defence, Electronics, Semiconductor, and Artificial Intelligence (ESAI), headquartered in Bangalore, India, has announced a new win for its subsidiary, Mistral Solutions, in the Defence division. Mistral Solutions, a leader in high-performance embedded systems and defence electronics, today announced the receipt of an order valued at approximately ₹80 crore under the prestigious LCA Mk1A programme of Hindustan Aeronautics Ltd (HAL).
Submer, the full-stack AI infrastructure provider, has announced a strategic collaboration with Anant Raj Cloud, a subsidiary of Anant Raj Limited, to develop fully operational AI-ready data centres across India. The collaboration enables the rapid deployment of high-density, energy-efficient computing platforms designed to support sovereign and enterprise AI workloads at scale. This partnership serves as a primary example of the EU-India Trade Deal in action, bringing world-class liquid-cooling technology from Spain and combining it with India’s robust infrastructure and operational support. Crucially, the collaboration strengthens a single, accountable source for AI data centre design, build, and scalable operation. Combined with Submer’s neocloud and inference platform, InferX, the partnership enables customers to access AI-ready infrastructure and compute through a unified, end-to-end model aligned with India’s sovereignty requirements.
Published on  February 10, 2026

headline: Indo-National Consolidated December 2025 Net Sales at Rs 106.31 crore, down 12.6% Y-o-Y

headline: Q3 results impact: Amber Enterprises stock up 6% as net loss narrows QoQ; Bata India gains 4.5%, Ramco Cements down 3%
condensed_text:
Q3 results impact: Amber Enterprises stock up 6% as net loss narrows QoQ; Bata India gains 4.5%, Ramco Cements down 3%. Amber Enterprises
Shares of Amber Enterprises Ltd rose 6% on February 10 after the company reported a net loss for the second consecutive quarter but it narrowed sequentially. Bata India
Shares of Bata India rose 4.5% to Rs 926.25 apiece on February 10 as the footwear chain owner posted 13% rise in Q3 profit, helped by festive demand and consumption tax cut and revenue was up 3%. Ramco Cements
Ramco Cements slips after missing estimates for quarterly core profit
Shares of Ramco Cements declined 3% to Rs 1,172 apiece on February 10 as the South India-focussed cement maker posted a rise in third-quarter profit but fell short of volume growth expectations
Brokerages Jefferies, Motilal Oswal Financial Services and Emkay said the company's EBITDA missed estimates due to double whammy of weak volumes and weak pricing in its core markets of Southern and Eastern India
Intense competition hurt pricing, said Jefferies while giving "hold" rating. The brokerage also noted the expansion of non-cement segments like construction chemicals worth monitoring for revenue diversification as cement competition intensifies
So far in 2026, the stock rose 10%.
full_content:
Shares ofAmber Enterprises, Bata India, Ramco Cements reacted on February 10 post-announcement of December quarter results.
Amber Enterprises
Shares of Amber Enterprises Ltd rose 6% on February 10 after the company reported a net loss for the second consecutive quarter but it narrowed sequentially. However, the company's top line posted a double-digit on-year growth for the latest quarter, while also beating analysts' estimate for its revenue from operations.
Amber Enterprises reported a consolidated net loss of Rs 27 crore for the December quarter. This was, however, lower than the net loss of Rs 36 crore reported in the September quarter. The company's revenue from operations for the reporting quarter rose almost 38% on year to Rs 2,943 croore. The company's total expenses growth for Oct-Dec was almost similar to its revenue growth for the quarter.
At 10:55 am on February 10, Amber Enterprises shares were trading 5.7% higher at Rs 7,448 apiece.
Bata India
Shares of Bata India rose 4.5% to Rs 926.25 apiece on February 10 as the footwear chain owner posted 13% rise in Q3 profit, helped by festive demand and consumption tax cut and revenue was up 3%.
So far in 2026, the stock fell 1.6%.
Ramco Cements
Ramco Cements slips after missing estimates for quarterly core profit
Shares of Ramco Cements declined 3% to Rs 1,172 apiece on February 10 as the South India-focussed cement maker posted a rise in third-quarter profit but fell short of volume growth expectations
Brokerages Jefferies, Motilal Oswal Financial Services and Emkay said the company's EBITDA missed estimates due to double whammy of weak volumes and weak pricing in its core markets of Southern and Eastern India
Intense competition hurt pricing, said Jefferies while giving "hold" rating.
The brokerage also noted the expansion of non-cement segments like construction chemicals worth monitoring for revenue diversification as cement competition intensifies
So far in 2026, the stock rose 10%.

headline: Poly Medicure says margins dip was one-off, growth to improve in the second half
condensed_text: Delhi-based medical device maker Poly Medicure expects growth to be stronger in the second half compared to the first, with the company likely to end the year with an overall growth of around 20%.Himanshu Baid, Managing Director of Poly Medicure said the initial slowdown was largely due to softness in overseas markets, but that trend has started to reverse, providing better visibility on revenues going ahead.On the domestic side, the company is tracking overall growth of about 21–22%, led by the private segment, which is growing at a faster pace of around 25%.He said the margin impact during the third quarter was a one-off, mainly due to labour code changes and acquisition-related costs. He expects margins to improve from here as these exceptional costs fall away and the newly acquired subsidiaries scale up and improve their profitability.Baid remains optimistic about the next financial year, with subsidiaries expected to contribute more meaningfully and export markets in Europe and the US reopening after earlier delays.Europe is already showing signs of improvement, and export growth of 12–15% is currently visible, with clearer guidance expected by the end of the fourth quarter.In October-December quarter , Poly Medicure reported a revenue of ₹493 crore, profit of ₹70 crore and margins of 23%.These are edited excerpts of the interview.Q: This year is going to be obviously a lower than estimated growth. This was a one-off quarter on a consolidated basis, the net margin level, but in terms of gross margins, we have improved by actually 200-300 basis points in the current quarter.Q: Margin should get back to 25-27% and on the topline you maintain the 15 to 16% growth guidance?A: If you see a current quarter, we have done close to 15-16% growth from the previous quarter, and this quarter also will see a similar number. Next year also, we should see a similar growth unless, until there is a big change in the duty structure, or there is something intervention by the government, we don't see moving back to that 35-40% number.Q: Have you reached out to the government, for some sort of protection against dumping by China on renal products?A: We have reached out and we are working on that. Hopefully government is working on it and we will see something in next few months coming up.Q: On this India US trade deal for medtech products, the tariff has been cut from 15 to 18% if you could give perspective on the industry, what percentage is India's exports to the US from an industry point of view, how would it compare with, say, you know, from a country like China?
full_content: Delhi-based medical device maker Poly Medicure expects growth to be stronger in the second half compared to the first, with the company likely to end the year with an overall growth of around 20%.Himanshu Baid, Managing Director of Poly Medicure said the initial slowdown was largely due to softness in overseas markets, but that trend has started to reverse, providing better visibility on revenues going ahead.On the domestic side, the company is tracking overall growth of about 21–22%, led by the private segment, which is growing at a faster pace of around 25%.He said the margin impact during the third quarter was a one-off, mainly due to labour code changes and acquisition-related costs. He expects margins to improve from here as these exceptional costs fall away and the newly acquired subsidiaries scale up and improve their profitability.Baid remains optimistic about the next financial year, with subsidiaries expected to contribute more meaningfully and export markets in Europe and the US reopening after earlier delays.Europe is already showing signs of improvement, and export growth of 12–15% is currently visible, with clearer guidance expected by the end of the fourth quarter.In October-December quarter , Poly Medicure reported a revenue of ₹493 crore, profit of ₹70 crore and margins of 23%.These are edited excerpts of the interview.Q: This year is going to be obviously a lower than estimated growth. As you said, the first couple of quarters were rough, and it appears most of the growth has come in because of the acquisition. Now, given that the acquisition will be fully available for the entire of FY27 what kind of growth are you looking at if you break it up between the exports as well as the domestic market, because there was some softness even in the domestic market?A: So domestic market, has grown around 22.50%. If you look at the private market, it is almost 90% of our business. Government business, there was a deliberate attempt to make it slightly lower, because of the margin pressure there. So overall, we have grown 18% close to 18% on the domestic business. But a private business which is 90% has grown around has grown around 22%.Hopefully, we will end the year, roughly overall growth in the domestic business close to 21-22%, but private business will grow by around 25%. When you look at next year, we have not guided fully, but next year we should grow back. The subsidiaries will start kicking, in export business, which was stalled a little bit in Europe and US, the trade deal is signed. So now we are back on track. Hopefully, the contracts which were stalled will come back very quickly, we are working on them.Europe market seems to be looking better now, much better than before. So, export business will show a growth of between 12 to 15% that's what we see right now, but I think we will quantify the numbers at end of quarter four.Q: Your margins have contracted on a year on year basis. What led to that, and what is the guidance on margins? Was this a one off, do margins recover back again in quarter four or are lower margins going to be the new normal for the company?A: This was a one-off situation. We had almost ₹7 crore of new labour code impact, of around ₹9-9.5 crore of acquisition costs were absorbed in quarter three. So, barring that, if you look at standalone numbers, we did EBITDA of 26.8%, if we combine it on the whole consolidated basis, it was around 24.2% because the subsidiaries, the acquisitions we did, have started kicking in. Of course, they operated lower EBITDA margin right now because we've just acquired these companies. But as we go along, they will also increase their margins. This was a one-off quarter on a consolidated basis, the net margin level, but in terms of gross margins, we have improved by actually 200-300 basis points in the current quarter.Q: Margin should get back to 25-27% and on the topline you maintain the 15 to 16% growth guidance?A: If you see a current quarter, we have done close to 15-16% growth from the previous quarter, and this quarter also will see a similar number. As we told earlier, between H1 and H2 we will see a 20% growth, because first few quarters were really down because of international revenue, but international revenue will has started coming back. We will end the year between H1 and H2 with a 20% growth. But of course, next year looks more promising.Q: You have scaled down your dialysis machine sales. Earlier, you were looking at 500 to 550 that's around 450 odd. Are you confident about meeting this revised guidance? And how do you see that trajectory move from year on, in terms of number of machines, if you could tell us, 27, 28 onwards, and also the Renal business, that is a smaller part of your business, but you were quite optimistic on growth out there. So what revenue is this year, next year, and how do you see that shaping up?A: The renal business has taken a small dip, mainly because of, dumping from Chinese companies. I have been talking constantly about it, and because of the FTAs they have been using nearby countries like Malaysia, Thailand, Vietnam, to dump products in India at zero duty. That is what is hurting the industry - number one.Number two, on the machine side, also we have a similar problem because, some of those equipment’s are coming from those countries and with a zero duty and that is also hurting our manufacturing here. So currently, we should end the year with around 25 to 28% growth.Nine months, we are down close to around 25% growth. But we should end around 25 to 28% growth for the whole year. Next year also, we should see a similar growth unless, until there is a big change in the duty structure, or there is something intervention by the government, we don't see moving back to that 35-40% number.Q: Have you reached out to the government, for some sort of protection against dumping by China on renal products?A: We have reached out and we are working on that. We have, raised that issue at different levels, the commerce ministry and with the pharmaceutical ministry.Q: How much cheaper are the Chinese products versus, say, Poly Medicure?A: The bigger problem is they have been selling below the import price, that's a bigger concern that, how could somebody sell a product in India below the import cost? I think that is a concern we have raised with the government. Hopefully government is working on it and we will see something in next few months coming up.Q: On this India US trade deal for medtech products, the tariff has been cut from 15 to 18% if you could give perspective on the industry, what percentage is India's exports to the US from an industry point of view, how would it compare with, say, you know, from a country like China? And then lay out the impact for Poly Medicure because I think for you US, exports are still very small?A: If you see from India's total export basket of $4 billion, US export was close to around $750 million and mainly these are large equipment’s. Probably larger companies are exporting some equipment’s back to US. Consumer export is still not very high, but with the trade deal signed, what I see is a major impact coming in the medtech industry, because many because many projects were stalled, and we lost many opportunities to countries like Malaysia, Vietnam and maybe Thailand, because they had lower tariffs compared to India. So, no new projects were coming, and most of the projects got stalled.This is a very, very positive move, even for us, because we have almost 10 to 15 products in pipeline, which were on the verge of getting into the US market. So hopefully, we will start working on them and the companies we were working with, they will come back very quickly to us on that. And also, we get more competitive with China, for sure in terms of like to like basis.For full interview, watch accompanying videoLive stock market updates—follow our blog
